history.subject: Welcome to Piazza!
history.content:
Piazza is a Q&A platform designed to get you great answers from classmates and instructors fast. We've put together this list of tips you might find handy as you get started:
  1. Ask questions! The best way to get answers is to ask questions! Ask questions on Piazza rather than emailing your teaching staff so everyone can benefit from the response (and so you can get answers from classmates who are up as late as you are).
  2. Edit questions and answers wiki-style. Think of Piazza as a Q&A wiki for your class. Every question has just a single students' answer that students can edit collectively (and a single instructors’ answer for instructors).
  3. Add a followup to comment or ask further questions. To comment on or ask further questions about a post, start a followup discussion. Mark it resolved when the issue has been addressed, and add any relevant information back into the Q&A above.
  4. Go anonymous. Shy? No problem. You can always opt to post or edit anonymously.
  5. Tag your posts. It's far more convenient to find all posts about your Homework 3 or Midterm 1 when the posts are tagged. Type a “#” before a key word to tag. Click a blue tag in a post or the question feed to filter for all posts that share that tag.
  6. Format code and equations. Adding a code snippet? Click the pre or tt button in the question editor to add pre-formatted or inline teletype text. Mathematical equation? Click the Fx button to access the LaTeX editor to build a nicely formatted equation.
  7. View and download class details and resources.
Click the Course Page button in your top bar to access the class syllabus, staff contact information, office hours details, and course resources—all in one place! Contact the Piazza Team anytime with questions or comments at team@piazza.com. We love feedback!

history.subject: Office Hours
history.content:
First off, if you have not already done so please join the course Piazza. Important announcements and information will be posted there going forward.Office hours will start today, you can find the schedule here (will be updated on Saturday):
  • Mon, Tues, Wed 4-10
  • Thurs 4-6
  • Sat, Sun 2-6

All office hours will be held in Skirkanich 114 (Greenberg Lounge). We will use ohq.io to manage the office hours queue.Office hours are held in person. However, if you are sick/exposed to COVID-19 please do not come to office hours in person. In these circumstances you may post a Zoom link in your OHQ question with an explanation for why you are not attending. We reserve the right to request formal proof if we feel that this policy is being abused.

Further, here are some notes about joining office hours on OHQ and general etiquette we ask that you abide by:
  • All questions should include the following:
    • The homework question number you are asking about
    • What specifically you are having trouble with
    • What methods you have already tried
If your question does not contain these we will skip you until it does. If the queue is long you may be removed.
  • Questions should not be about validating your solution (such as “I’m confused about whether my solution is right.” or “Not sure if I have the right intuition.“). TAs have been instructed not to answer questions like these. We expect that you have already worked on the problem prior to asking for help.
  • When the queue is sufficiently long (i.e., wait time is over 20 minutes), we will only be able to spend up to 5 minutes with each student to better ensure we help students make progress on the assignment and reduce wait times. This means that you may only be able to ask one question at a time.

#pin

history.subject: HW01 Released & FAQ!
history.content:
Hello everyone!

Welcome to CIS1600! We have just released the first homework, and it is now accessible on Canvas! Note that all future homeworks will also be released on Canvas. This first homework will be due on Wednesday, January 18 at 11:59PM Eastern Time.

We ask that you write up all of your solutions in LaTeX. We will be covering some of the basics of LaTeX in recitation this week. To help get you started on the homeworks, we have provided you a template, which you should download and write your solutions into. This template can be found on Canvas. Homeworks should be uploaded to Gradescope. For more information regarding homeworks, please check the course syllabus.

We will be updating this Piazza post throughout the week with FAQ regarding this homework, so please be sure to check this post consistently.

Please make sure that you read the Self-Paced Activities in the current module. They are very helpful for some of the problems.

Please look through this FAQ, previous posts, and use the search bar to look for your question before posting a new question as per our Piazza policy.

 

General notes/questions:

  • You must rigorously prove any concepts not taught in lecture or recitation in order to use them on the homework. 

FAQ

Q1: $$\mathcal{P}(A)$$ is equivalent to $$2^A$$.

Q2:

Q3:

Q4:

Q5:

Q6:

Q7:

  • If the two beach balls chosen have the same number, they are thrown away and replaced with a beach ball numbered 0.

history.subject: Q7 Clarification
history.content: <md>Let's say the first two beach balls selected are $$1$$ and $$2023$$. These are thrown away, and $$2022$$ is put back in the pool. Now let's say the next two beach balls selected are $$2022$$ and $$2022$$. These are thrown away, but they do not have a positive difference. In this case, is no beach ball thrown back in?</md>
<md>Answered in FAQ Q7.</md>
In this case 0 would be added to the pool. We specify positive difference to indicate that you always subtract the smaller number from the larger number.

history.subject: Proving a number is an integer
history.content: How do we prove that a number is an integer?

If you're just looking at a number, say 7, you can just say that it is an integer. But if it is a more abstract quantity (such as the product/sum of other numbers/variables), then some sort of justification based on the closure of integers would suffice.

For example, suppose I want to show that $$k = 2x + y$$ is an integer. And suppose we know that $$x$$ and $$y$$ are integers, then you could just say that $$k$$ is an integer because $$x$$ and $$y$$ are integers and the integer set is closed under addition and multiplication.

You may assume $$p\cdot p = p^2$$.

history.subject: When taking a cross product, are the resultant pairs in the set ordered?
history.content: Eg if I have A = {1,2} and B = {3, 4), then does A x B contain the term (4, 2)? I'd imagine no, but am not totally sure.
No. The definition of cross product is $$A imes B = \{(a, b) \mid a \in A \wedge b \in B\}$$. Since $$4 otin A$$ and $$2 otin B$$, then it must be that $$(4, 2) otin A imes B$$
No

history.subject: Question for 3 (b)
history.content:
2^183 + 1 = (2 + 1)(2^182 − 2^181 + · · · − 2 + 1).
Let’s denote (2 + 1) by r and (2^182 − 2^181 + · · · − 2 + 1) by s. Then both r and s are factors
of 2^183 + 1. Since 1 < r < s and they are both positive integer factors which are neither 1
nor equal to 2^183 + 1, we can see that 2^183 + 1 is a composite number

In the proof above, do we have to prove that r<s?
This is something you should think about

sure

think about the definition you came up with for composite. Does it matter how the factors compare to one another?

history.subject: Empty Intersection
history.content: For the question on lecture notes 1.6, they mention that three sets have an "empty intersection." Does this just mean that all three of the sets contain the empty set? What is an "empty intersection"?
Three sets $$A, B, C$$ have an "empty intersection" if $$A \cap B \cap C = \emptyset$$

history.subject: Do we have to/is there a way we can prove an integer squared is an integer?

history.content: you don't have to prove this

Consider a combinatorial argument: you have n people. In how many ways could you choose two people, with replacement, among these n? You have n choices for the first, and n choices for the second, so n^2. You don't cut any people in half during this process -- the people stay people. Then the fundamental property of n is the same, and you have an integer.

Consider a combinatorial argument: you have n people. In how many ways could you choose two people, with replacement, among these n? You have n choices for the first, and n choices for the second, so n^2. You don't cut any people in half during this process -- the people stay people. Then the fundamental property of n is the same, and you ahve an integer.

history.subject: Is AxBxC the same as (AxB)xC
history.content: title

Yes and no.

PLEASE AVOID GIVING ANSWERS LIKE THIS. THIS IS MATH. VAL

To elaborate, would you say that (x, (y, z)) is the same as ((x, y), z)? That would imply that (x, y) = x and (y, z) = z, so ((x, y), z) = (x, y, z) is meaningless. However, there is a tacit bijection

AND WE SHOULD EXPLAIN "BIJECTION" IF WE USE IT. VAL

between the terms, so you could consider them the same (and you do in higher division math). It comes down to an interpretation, and I guess it's really up to what the solution *ought* to be. It'll be up to the professor to choose what his preferred answer is in general.

A x B x C is not well-defined, you need the parenthesis.

children.subject: so the answer for (AxB)XC would be a tuple inside a tuple?
Yup

Bettina, I discussed the difference between $$(A\times B)\times C$$  and $$A\times(B\times C)$$ is yesterdays (Tue 1/17) IS, please see recordings.

They are different, unless at least one of the sets $$A,B,C$$ is empty.

We did not define $$A\times B\times C$$ (no parentheses) but one could do that, by the following set-builder: $$\{(a,b,c)\mid a\in A ~\mbox{and}~ b\in B~ \mbox{and} ~c\in C\}$$.

Note that this differs from both the above.

@Val Tannen Thanks for the elaboration, but I'm a bit confused by this answer, because it sort of implies that they're *not* canonically isomorphic by a unique isomorphism. The associator between (AxB)xC and Ax(BxC) is a canonical functorial isomorphism, which is both covariant in all variables and unique. If you say they're not *associative*, then you're sort of denying an equivalence invariance which feels *morally* wrong.

Gear, please email me directly at val@seas.upenn.edu

Everybody else, please ignore Gear's post.

In short, a closed form expression is essentially a term which can be evaluated in a fixed finite number of operations. Some examples would be $$1, x^2 + 1$$ or $$2n$$.

Examples of expressions that are not closed form usually involve summations with non-constant bounds such as $$\sum_{i=1}^n i$$. We'll be posting a more in-depth description of what closed form is on piazza very soon. 

Update: @138

In short, a closed form expression is essentially a term which can be evaluated in a fixed finite number of operations. Some examples would be $$1, x^2 + 1$$ or $$2n$$.

Examples of expressions that are not closed form usually involve summations with non-constant bounds such as $$\sum_{i=1}^n i$$. We'll be posting a more in-depth description of what closed form is on piazza very soon.

history.subject: Closed Form
history.content:
Hi all,

Now that some of the exercises require mathematical expressions as answers, we need to clarify what forms of answer are acceptable.

In CIS 1600, all final expressions (to questions requiring mathematical expressions as answers) should be in closed form unless explicitly stated otherwise. A closed form expression is essentially a term which can be evaluated in a fixed finite number of operations. For reference, many terms we will encounter are in closed form: $$12$$, $$x^2+1$$, $$k!$$,  $$2n$$, $$\binom{n}{k}$$, $$\sum_{i = 1}^{5} i^2$$.

The most likely exceptions you will encounter are summations or products whose bounds are variables. For example, $$\sum_{i = 1}^{n} (2i - 1)$$ or $$1+3+5+⋯+(2n−1)$$ would not be considered closed form, since we have a variable bound $$n$$ (the number of terms we are adding is not fixed). However, the equivalent value $$n^2$$ is closed form (we haven’t yet proven this equality, so you can’t use this post as justification if we ask for this identity, but we will likely do so in due time). Similarly, if you have nested summations, e.g. $$\sum_{i = 1}^{100} \sum_{k = 1}^{i} k$$, we would not consider this closed form since the inner summation has variable bounds.

Furthermore, if you simplify an open form expression to a closed form expression, you must prove their equivalence using only material we have learned in this course. We generally strongly advise against this as it almost always entails unnecessarily complex justification. All problems in this course can be answered without doing this.

We require closed form for full credit, even if it is not explicitly asked for (we will try to include a reminder in most cases where an open form solution is viable). In general, if you’re not sure whether something is closed form, feel free to ask on Piazza (as always, if you’re worried about possibly giving away too much, you can post privately) or in office hours!

history.subject: Module 2.6: Clarification on the quiz question

history.content: what exactly do you have a question about here?

children.subject: The explanation given wasn't clear. Can someone please explain how to determine that?

There are more partial permutations of 2 elements out of 4 elements than there are combinations of 2 elements out of 4 elements.

One way to argue this is numerically: The amount of combinations of 2 elements out of 4 elements is $$\binom{4}{2} = 6$$. The number of partial permutations of 2 elements is $$\frac{4!}{2!} = 12$$ and we clearly see that $$12 > 6$$.

For a more qualitative argument, we can think of constructing a partial permutation as a two step procedure where in the first step, we select 2 of the four elements, and then in the second step, we arrange those two elements. Note that the number of ways the first step can be performed is equivalent to the number of combinations of 2 elements. And for each of those combinations, there are $$2!$$ ways to arrange the two elements within the permutation.

Lastly, another thing I will highlight is that the main difference between combinations and permutations is that with permutations, the order of the values matters. That is, if we had four elements $$\{1, 2, 3, 4\}$$ and we wanted to find a valid combination of 2 elements, the two elements $$\{1, 2\}$$ would suffice. However, when considering combinations, $$\{1, 2\}$$ would be the same as $$\{2, 1\}$$ (because order doesn't matter. With permutations, these would be different cases.

history.subject: Q4) Logical Connective for "necessary"
history.content: Is the logical connective for "necessary" "if and only if (iff)" or is it "implies (=>)"?
Necessary would be $$\impliedby$$ “implied by”

children.subject:
Is a implies b the same as b is implied by a

ie a => b is the same as b <=a
Yes

Hi, I don't quite understand how to use the logical connective. If it is necessary to have eggs to bake a cake, is baking a cake implied by having eggs? And therefore, does having eggs imply baking a cake? Or am I missing something?

One way to think about the statement "it is necessary to have eggs to bake a cake" is the following: since it's necessary to have eggs to bake a cake, if we don't have eggs, then we cannot bake a cake. This can be phrased as "don't have eggs $$\implies$$ cannot bake cake", and this statement is the contrapositive of, and thus logically equivalent to, the statement "can bake cake $$\implies$$ has eggs" or "If we can bake a cake, then we have eggs."
Thank you so much, this helped a lot.

history.subject: s.t.
history.content:
<md>Do I need to explicitly state "such that" ($$s.t.$$) when using set-builder notation with $$\exists$$? For instance, is it valid to rewrite the following:

$$\{ x\ \vert\ \exists k \in \mathbb{N}\ s.t. x = 2k \}$$

as:

$$\{ x\ \vert\ \exists k \in \mathbb{N}\  x = 2k \}$$
?</md>
no, it is not necessary, but it is nice to include for clarity.

history.subject: Notate set of integers from a to b
history.content:
<md>Is this a valid way to say for all integers from $$1$$ to $$100$$?

$$\forall k \in \{1, 2, ..., 100\}$$</md>

history.subject: Notate set of integers from a to b
history.content:
<md>Is this a valid way to say that $$k$$ represents all integers from $$1$$ to $$100$$?

$$\forall k \in \{1, 2, ..., 100\}$$</md>
this reads as "for all k in the set 1, 2, ..., 100". As a standalone statement, it doesn't really mean too much, so typically this would be followed by some other condition/fact about $$k$$

history.subject: Parentheses in set-builder notation
history.content:
<md>Are we allowed to put parentheses in set-builder notation to be more clear?

e.g. $$\{  x\mid (0 < x < 100)\ \land\ (x \in \mathbb{N})\}$$</md>
yep that's fine

history.subject: Disproving
history.content: When disproving something, is it sufficient to follow the regular proof pattern and then just point out when something goes wrong? In other words, should we always "attempt" to prove something and then if something goes wrong call it disproved? Or is there a separate approach that we use specifically for disproving something?

no, this would not be sufficient. This is because there may be multiple ways of proving something, so just finding something wrong in one proof pattern may not cover all possible proofs. 

One way of disproving is in the case where you are proving a universal property and provide a counterexample.

history.subject: Is there a specific name for the equation below?
history.content: not(A and B) = not A or not B
That is demorgan’s law!

children.subject: Can we use it?
You can use it in a logical statement (i.e., you may assume that $$\lnot(p\land q)\equiv(\lnot p)\lor (\lnot q)$$ for any propositions $$p,q$$).

history.subject: The name of the following equation
history.content:
a and (b or c) = (a and b) or (a and c)

What is the name of this equation?
This is the distributive property of logical "and" over logical "or".

children.subject: Are we allowed to use this property without proving it?
You may use this property for logical statements without proving it.

history.subject: Femmehacks 2023 FYI
history.content:
FemmeHacks is back in person  at Pennovation Center for its 9th year on Feb 10-11th, 2023! And we would love to see you and your students there. FemmeHacks is a collegiate hackathon hosted by Women in Computer Science at the University of Pennsylvania and is meant for students in the greater Philadelphia area. Our event is a great way for women* of all skill levels to learn new programming skills, network with each other, and collaborate in making awesome apps. We aim to inspire, teach, and empower young women in the Philly tech community by hosting educational workshops and providing a fun environment where they can create lasting bonds.


In recent hackathons, we’ve had a hacker-to-mentor ratio of 4-to-1. We’ll also be handing out FemmeHacks swag, such as t-shirts, to all eligible participants. We also have an abundance of in-person workshops this year, such as arts and crafts stations and more!

Check out our website and the flyer attached for additional info, and register here by February 3rd to ensure a spot! Feel free to email us any questions you have at pennfemmehacks@gmail.com.

Thanks for making it this far, and we hope to see you there!

With love ,

The FemmeHacks Team


FemmeHacks Facebook


FemmeHacks Instagram


*We realize "women" is a complicated term. All trans/cis/non-binary/gender non-conforming folks are welcomed!

history.subject: Question 8 - Notation Question
history.content:
Is it appropriate/ is there a way to use summation notation to run through the elements of a set?

ex:

$$\sum_{n=z}^{S} ({2^{|z|} -1}) = ....$$

S is a set of sets (like a power set)

z is an element of S (meaning z is a set)

|z| is the cardinality of z

Please let me know if I can clarify this question.
Yeah, the notation would be as follows: $$\sum_{z \in S} (2^{|z|} - 1)$$

children.subject: Just a quick follow up.... this iterates through a set in the same way we could loop through a list in java? Like it just starts at the first element and ends at the last element???
No. The notation I provided does not impose an ordering on the way elements are processed. But it does process every element. The order is just arbitrary.
Also would the above in the initial question be considered closed form???

First note that sets are unordered, so you cannot iterate through it like a list. The only proper way to sum over a set is the answer provided by Ishaan.

In regards to closed form, if you use Ishaan's equation then it depends on what $$S$$ is. If $$S$$ is a completely defined set like $$S = 2^A$$ where $$A = \{1, 2\}$$, here we can fully write out the elements of $$S$$ as $$S = \{ \emptyset, \{1\}, \{2\}, \{1, 2\} \}$$ so the equation is closed form.

For an example of when it is not closed form, consider $$S = 2^A$$ where $$A = [1..n]$$, $$n \in \mathbb{Z}^+$$ (positive integers between $$1$$ and $$n$$), then the equation would not be in closed form because there are a variable number of elements in $$S$$.
So in the context of question 8..... any if set S = $$2^n$$...... this notation would be closed form...... because n is SOME positive integer as opposed to every positive integer?
No, $$n$$ in the example I provided is some positive integer, not every. As long as you don't know the value of $$n$$, the equation is not closed form.

Sorry... I am still a bit confused based on the definition of closed form pinned in piazza.... "In CIS 1600, all final expressions (to questions requiring mathematical expressions as answers) should be in closed form unless explicitly stated otherwise. A closed form expression is essentially a term which can be evaluated in a fixed finite number of operations. For reference, many terms we will encounter are in closed form: 12, x2+1, k!,  2n, $$n \choose k$$,..... "

..... I understand that the bound of a summation cannot be n and that this would not be closed form.... but why would the equivalent $n^2$ be considered closed form? ie: if we are doing an operation on n or defining a set using n.... would the summation be considered closed form.

Ex: 

$$\sum_{z \in S} ({2^{|z|} -1}) = ....$$

where S = $$2^n$$

$$n^2$$ requires a fixed, finite number of operations. It always requires one operation (the operation being a single multiplication between two values). No matter the value of $$n$$, evaluating $$n^2$$ will always require one operation.

The summation with a variable bound does not have a fixed number of operations, because the value of the variable changes the amount of additions we are doing, and is hence not closed form.

history.subject: 2.sp2: How do we know for sure that (A \ B) ∪ (A ∩ B) ⊆ A given x belongs to A?
history.content:
Hi!


I just got a bit confuse on the way that the proof on 2.sp2 was done ((A \ B) ∪ (A ∩ B) ⊆ A ). I understood all the mathematical computations on why x belongs to A, but got stuck on the reasoning why by given that x ⊆ A,  (A \ B) ∪ (A ∩ B) ⊆ A  must be true. Why couldn't it be the other way around where A ⊆ (A \ B) ∪ (A ∩ B) ? 

Thanks in advance!

Well that conclusion is being made because we are under the case of showing that $$(A \setminus B) \cup (A \cap B) \subseteq A$$. Remember, to show equality, we show inclusion in both directions. So focusing on the direction $$(A \setminus B) \cup (A \cap B) \subseteq A$$, we would want to show that for any element that appears in the left hand side, it must also appear in the right hand side. 2.sp2 argues that for any element $$x \in (A \setminus B) \cup (A \cap B)$$, we have $$x \in A$$, so we have that any element in the left hand side also appears in the right hand side (since x was arbitrary), and by definition of subset, we conclude that the left hand side is a subset of the right hand side. 

We then go on to show the inclusion in the other direction. And to show that, we would go about taking an arbitrary element of $$A$$ and show that it appears in $$(A \setminus B) \cup (A \cap B)$$.

I think the key thing to note is the definition of subset. We have $$A \subset B$$ if and only if for every element $$a \in A$$, we also have $$a \in B$$. That's what we are doing in the set proofs; we consider an element $$a \in A$$ and then show that it must be that $$a \in B$$ and then conclude that $$A \subseteq B$$

children.subject: Thank you. Can we just call "or" "or" operators or union? Does the naming not matter
There is a difference between $$\vee$$ and $$\cup$$. We use $$\vee$$ to denote logical OR. We use $$\cup$$ to denote union.
I am confused. What is the difference between them? A or B would still be A U B, doesn't it?

$$\vee$$ is an operation used on two propositions. $$\cup$$ is an operation used on two sets. So, for example, if $$A = \{1, 2\}$$ and $$B = \{3, 4\}$$, then $$A \vee B$$ would not mean anything. However, $$A \cup B$$ would denote the union of the two sets and we have $$A \cup B = \{1, 2, 3, 4\}$$.

Similarly, if we let $$p = \text{My name is Ishaan}$$ and $$q = \text{I am a CIS1600 TA}$$. Then $$p \vee q = \text{My name is Ishaan OR I am a CIS1600 TA}$$, but $$p \cup q$$ means nothing.

The way the two relate is that if you have an element $$x \in A \cup B$$, then you could say that $$x \in A$$ OR $$x \in B$$. Written symbolically, we have $$x \in A \cup B \implies x \in A \vee x \in B$$.

history.subject: Question 5b
history.content: if we define an arbitrary variable that covers all cases then should we say WLOG

This isn't necessary, you can just say let x be an element of the set. We use WLOG in cases where we make symmetric arguments. For example, if you're proving that the sum of an even and odd number is odd, you can define your numbers as x and y, and assume that x is even and y is odd WLOG to then show that x + y is odd. We can use WLOG here because our proof would be symmetrical if instead x were odd and y were even.

history.subject: 3.1 Question
history.content: For the donuts example in 3.1, could you also count the number of ways as 5^12, since there are 5 choices of glaze for each of the 12 donuts?

<md>This highlights the importance of distinguishability. $$5^{12}$$ would be correct if all donuts were distinguishable. However, the problem states that donuts of the same glaze are indistinguishable, so $$5^{12}$$ overcounts. 

Consider CCCCCCEEEDDD and EEECCCDDDCCC. These would be two different outcomes with your procedure. However, they are the same outcome of 6 C's, 3 E's, and 3 D's. Given the indistinguishability of donuts of the same glaze, stars and bars is the appropriate approach.</md>

  • Per @331, in part c, the question should read, "how many ways can you distribute these elements to 5 disjoint, distinguishable bags such that each bag contains at least one element and the elements b, i, t are distributed to different bags".
  • In part c, the bags are already distinguishable-- having the same letter makeup doesn't change that. (i.e. having {r, r} in bag 1 and {r, r} in bag 2 is fine). 
  • In part c, "disjoint bags" for indistinguishable letters does not mean that two bags cannot both have the letter "r". It means that the total number of r's in all of the bags added up must be 23.

history.subject: False implies anything
history.content: Can you please explain further what "false implies anything" means? It was mentioned in Tuesday's interactive session but I'm not sure I fully understand it.

$$p \implies q$$ can be interpreted as "if $$p$$ happens, then $$q$$ will definitely happen," so $$p \implies q$$ is true if for all occurrences where $$p$$ happens, $$q$$ also happens. 

When $$p$$ never happens (as in it is always false), then it is true that for all occurrences where $$p$$ happens, $$q$$ also happens, thus $$p \implies q$$ is true.

$$p \implies q$$ can be interpreted as "if $$p$$ happens, then $$q$$ will definitely happen," so $$p \implies q$$ is true if for all occurrences where $$p$$ happens, $$q$$ also happens. 

When $$p$$ never happens, then it is true that for all occurrences where $$p$$ happens, $$q$$ also happens, thus $$p \implies q$$ is true.

history.subject: Without Loss of Generality (WLOG) and Arbitrary
history.content:
<md># WLOG and Arbitrary
Hi everyone! Over the course of grading, we noticed that there may be some confusion as to the meaning of the phrases "without loss of generality" and "arbitrary," which potentially changed the intended meaning of solutions from one that was correct to one that was potentially incorrect. As such, we thought it'd be good to explain these phrases so you can use them in your proofs (as both are really helpful)!

## Without Loss of Generality (WLOG)
Without loss of generality is useful when there are symmetries in a problem. Consider the following statement that we might want to prove:

>Consider $$x$$ and $$y$$, where one is even and one is odd. Show that $$x + y$$ is odd.

Without WLOG, we might write the following:

> Case 1: $$x$$ is even, $$y$$ is odd. Then $$x = 2k, y = 2l + 1$$ for some integers $$k,l$$. Then, $$x + y = 2(k + 1) + 1$$, which is odd.

> Case 2: $$x$$ is odd, $$y$$ is even. Then $$x = 2k + 1, y = 2l $$ for some integers $$k,l$$. Then, $$x + y = 2(k + 1) + 1$$, which is odd. 

Notice how we duplicated a lot of our logic! Ideally, we'd love *not* to do that. And luckily, with WLOG, we can! Since addition commutes ($$x + y$$ = $$y + x$$), both of these cases are basically the same. I could basically **switch the names of the variables** and the proof is exactly the same. Therefore, I can say *without loss of generality* that $$x$$ is even, since the other case ($$x$$ odd) I can just switch the names of the variables and the order of addition and I would have the exact same case! So **we use WLOG when we have symmetries in the problem that can help us avoid casework**.

## Arbitrary
Arbitrary is used in a different setting. To illustrate the usage of this phrase, let's consider any proposition we want to prove using a universal quantifier (i.e., $$\forall x \in \mathcal{S}, P(x)$$ for some predicate $$P(\cdot)$$ and some set $$\mathcal{S}$$). I think of these as a conversation with an adversary -- the adversary chooses some value $$x$$ to give you from the set $$\mathcal{S}$$, and your job is to show that $$P(x)$$ is true. Your job, as the prover, is to do this for every single $$x$$ that the adversary could give you. That is, you need to give some procedure, on any $$x$$, which shows $$P(x)$$. This any $$x$$ we can say is an **arbitrary** value of $$x$$. So, we might say that for any *arbitrary* value the adversary gives us, do this procedure to show that $$P(x)$$ is true.

It's important to note that once you say something specific about $$x$$, (e.g., if you have a list $$l$$ and you say $$x$$ is the first element in the list), then it's no longer an arbitrary element of the list.
</md>

children.subject:
I would add a couple of things.

I did say in class that for cases that are essentially the same except for swapping some variables, you can say in proofs SIMILARLY

or can also say ANALOGOUSLY. As David wrote above, in this course we also accept WLOG in such situations.

I also use WLOG in the lectures in contexts that are a little different. Examples:

- "Suppose we know that at least one of the integers $$x,y,z$$ is even. WLOG we assume that $$x$$ is even."

This is somewhat similar to the use for cases that you saw in the post above.

- "Let $$A$$ be a non-empty finite set such that $$|A|=n$$. WLOG $$A=\{a_1,\ldots,a_n\}$$".

Here we need for the elements of $$A$$ names that can be further referenced in a proof. We invent the

names $$a_1,\ldots,a_n$$ for that purpose and this is WLOG because if we had chosen other names, say, $$b_1,\ldots,b_n$$

our proof would have been essentially the same, just swapping the $$a_i$$'s for the $$b_i$$'s.

history.subject: Question about stars and bars
history.content:
Hi, in relation to the stars and bars problem with the donuts in lecture 3.1, let's say we had 

CCC || EEEEEE | FFF | and DDD || FFFFFF | GGG. These are two different ways to choose donuts, but the bars are in the same location, so wouldn't 16 choose 4 be undercounting the ways to choose donuts?

The second arrangement is missing a bar; moreover, the second arrangement is not possible. We define the C donuts to be those that appear before the first bar, the D donuts to be those in between the first bar and second bar, etc.

Your second arrangement would be accurately represented as |DDD||FFFFF|GGG

history.subject: Questions on the interactive lecture 1/26
history.content:
I had a few conceptual questions from the lecture.

1. For the following screen, why is there a [] for the first line? I think I am having trouble with how "such that" is translated into logical notations and how the statements are connected. Is saying for all k ^ k is an integer ^ k>1 same as all integer k such that k>1? Basically, is such that an "and" operator? Because the professors states the 2nd line as "There is some k in Z, k>1 such that for any prime n, n is not between k and 2k" but for the logical notation it says some k in Z k>1 ^ (...)

2. Here, when we take the contrapositive, why is all x, y not turned into some x,y? Also, why does "in" stay the same instead of changing to "notin"? These assumptions and "such that" connections are the most confusing - is there a good resource to go through to understand them? Thank you.

1. "Such that" appears implicitly between the quantifier and the predicate. Using your example from the second line, we can think of the logical notation there exists some k in Z k>1 ^ (...) as being equivalent to there exists some k in Z such that k>1 ^ (...). You can think of "such that" as the phrase we use to precede the conditions which we want the elements we're quantifying to satisfy.

2. We're trying to prove that for all x and y in the integers, if the product of x and y is even, then at least one of x and y is even. When we think about taking the contrapositive, intuitively, the equivalent statement is that for all x and y in the integers, if x and y are both odd, then the product of x and y is odd. It wouldn't make sense to say that for some x and y in the integers, if x and y are both odd, then the product of x and y is odd because that means we would just need to find one example of some odd x and odd y and show that their product is odd to prove the original statement, whereas we really want to show that that holds for any possible x and y we pick. In other words, flipping the quantifier means x = 3, y = 5, xy = 15 is enough to show that the original statement holds, which isn't a valid proof.

The more general idea here is that quantifiers only get flipped if they are part of the logical statement you're trying to negate (i.e. negating for every x in the integers, x^2 is odd becomes for some x in the integers, x^2 is even), but not when when they aren't included in the logical statements you're trying to negate. In this problem, you're negating the statements "if the product of x and y is even" and "at least one of x and y is even", neither of which include a quantifier. The quantifier is used in this solution just as a way to enumerate all possible pairs of numbers we want to consider.

I just took a second look at the module slides, and they're talking about each bin needing a specific number $$n_i$$ of books. So for example, if we just have 2 bins and 3 books, and $$n_1=1$$ and $$n_2=2$$, the only way to do it would be to place one of the books in the first bin and place 2 of the books in the second. Since books are indistinguishable, this is the only way to do it.

history.subject: Cannot understand the last parts of lecture 3.6
history.content:
1. I understand the total ways to count anagrams. However, I am still not sure why "Now suppose that the bins are still labeled but the books are all copies of “Moby Dick”. In other words, the bins are distinguishable but the books are indistinguishable." Is only 1 way - isn't this the same as using stars and bars to divide the same books into different sections? Why would this be 1?

2. "Finally suppose that both the bins and books are indistinguishable." I also do not get why this is 1. Can you further elaborate on this?

3. Can we just use the formula for total ways of anagrams without proof?

4. What would be the way of distributing n distinct objects to m distinct people? I know that distributing n indistinguishable objects to m distinct people uses bars and stars but I am still confused about this concept.

Thank you!

1. This problem is different than stars and bars because the number of books in each bin is fixed: bin Bi will always contain ni elements. As an example, consider when n = 6 and we have three bins B1, B2 , and B3 where n1 = 1, n2 = 2, and n3 = 3. In this case, we need B1 to have exactly 1 book, B2 to have exactly 2 books, and B3 to have exactly 3 books. If all the books are indistinguishable, then there's only 1 way in which we could assign books to bins to satisfy this requirement. If we didn't have these restrictions on how many books needed to be in each bin and were just asked to find how many ways to distribute n books amongst k bins, then stars and bars would apply.

2. Pretty much for the same reason as number 1, we're restricted to only 1 possible outcome because of the size requirements on each bin.

3. Sure, if you show that what you're counting is equivalent to counting anagrams

4. This is something we'd like you to think about.

history.subject: Question 8C
history.content:
If something is not explicitly stated in the proof, does it still hold? 

What I mean is that in 8C the proof does not explicitly state that where a and b are positive a < b <=> a^2 < b^2. It just assumes that this is a two sided implication since both sides are positive and starts by working from the claim to a true statement. If we ignore the assumption, then a -> B and B is true does not mean that a has to be true, and the proof is invalid.

history.subject: 4.2 Question
history.content: Which sets are they referring to when they say the sets are pairwise disjoint? I thought if the sets were pairwise disjoint they could not have any elements in common.

Each $$S_i$$ is a set of sets, and it is true that the $$S_i$$'s are pairwise disjoint with respect to one another.

This is because, consider any two of these sets $$S_i$$ and $$S_j$$, for an arbitrary $$x \in S_i$$, we have $$|x| = i$$. However, we know that for any $$y \in S_j$$ we have $$|y| = j$$. So it always holds that $$x \notin S_j$$. This means that $$S_i \cap S_j = \emptyset$$ and thus are pairwise disjoint.

history.subject: 4.3 Question: Functions
history.content: How is the example above an example of a function? Doesn't a function require that every element of the domain maps to a unique element of the codomain? Here, both 2 and 3 map to the same element of the codomain.

A function only needs to map each element in the domain to exactly one element in the codomain. An injective function is one that maps at most one element to any given element in the codomain (so the function above is not injective).

history.subject: How I Should Go About Working Collaborately
history.content:
Hello,

I used to be a lone wolf in the HW assignments, but starting yesterday, I group of 2 recruited me in to be their 3rd member.

Just to make sure I don't get myself into trouble with the collaboration policy:

(Obviously, going forward, I need to remember to put both collaborators' names on my HW now.)

1. If someone is struggling with a problem but I know how to do it, should the general response be to tell them which slides to look at? Basically, give them a pointer but the onus is on them to understand the procedure and how to use the information we know.

2. While the page says that notes should be destroyed, would it best not to write anything down at all for them? I figured if they find out the general path, they should write a note about what to do on their Overleaf, and use that note later to write up a solution in their own words. What I don't want happening, is if they rely on me spelling out the solution for them, and that leads to similarities in our solutions, and thus, I get in trouble.

I think the best strategy is basically for everyone to write up the solutions from scratch (ie no notes, whether that is destroyed or just never existed). It's fine to be more specific than the slide they should look at (you can explain the strategy or what you are thinking about the problem) but when it comes to writing the solutions it should be entirely independent. 

TLDR: Nothing should go into Overleaf while you are together or with notes created while you are together.

children.subject:
So essentially, we can think of the discussion and writing up the solution as two totally different steps. And it is on myself and my group members to recall the procedure discussed during the session and fill in the details in their solutions.

Maybe I'm being overly paranoid, but perhaps as long as I always keep in mind to think of the discussion and writing up the solution from memory as separate, I shouldn't be worried about getting in trouble.
Yeah this is a good way of thinking about it

Also, naturally, the 3 of us in the group are going to have the same solution path and buzzwords, since we're discussing strategies for the problems. I'm assuming I shouldn't be worried about similarities in our solutions here.

What I should be worried about though, is how similarities in how we phrase, walk through, and articulate our solutions? But this would probably only be possible if I showed them my Overleaf directly, and this is obviously a huge no-no, so I shouldn't be concerned about similarity leading to trouble as long as I don't do this?

And another problem is, I usually don't like to peek at other peoples' laptops to respect their privacy but they could be secretly typing notes for themselves.

I think the best way to think about it is if you and your group don't violate the collaboration policy then there isn't anything to worry about. 

If you are worried about trusting your group-mates then maybe don't work with them.
Okay, perhaps at this point, I should not overthink it, not worry about stuff that isn't happening now, and just worry about myself.

history.subject: 5.5 PHP Sums of consecutive subsequences
history.content: Wouldn't 7 7 7 be a counterexample to this problem? I'm confused how the problem applies PHP, since can't all the "pigeons" (remainders) be in the same "pigeonhole" (all the remainders are the same)? So then the problem would not always occur?

If all the remainders were the same, then it would still be true that there's a hole with at least two pigeons (in this case, all the pigeons would be in the same hole). What the proof shows is that so long as there are at least two sums with the same remainder, we can form our desired sequence.

history.subject: What would be the core difference between the stars and bars technique and simple combinations?
What would be the core difference between the stars and bars technique and simple combinations?

history.content:
In one sentence: Stars and bars is an application of simple combinations.

For more detail, with simple combinations, such as $$\binom{n}{r}$$, we are simply considering a set of $$n$$ distinct items and determining how many ways can we choose $$r$$ of these items. Equivalently, this counts the number of subsets of size $$r$$ from our original set.

Stars and bars can be thought of as a two step procedure. We see a direct correlation between distributing indistinguishable items to distinguishable containers with an arrangement of stars and bars. So to count the number of ways to distribute, we count the number of arrangements of stars and bars. Suppose we have $$n$$ stars and $$r-1$$ bars, then our procedure would begin by choosing $$n$$ locations to put the stars. Since the remaining open slots must be filled with bars, they can only be filled in one way. So by MR, you get the familiar equation for stars and bars which is $$\binom{n + r - 1}{n}$$, or equivalently, $$\binom{n+r-1}{r-1}$$

or can we just go straight from $g(a) = g(b)$ and $a \neq b$ is false to saying that by contradiction we have shown that $g(a) = g(b) \implies a \neq b$.

history.subject: Recitation 4 Problem 3b
history.content: I was looking over the solutions for the Recitation 4 problems and am still a bit confused on how we came up with the two different cases for proving that f was surjective, specifically where the m + 1 came from.

Our goal in proving surjectivity is to show that for any arbitrary element in the codomain, say z, there's some element in the domain that gets mapped to z. For this problem, the domain is a set of ordered pairs defined by the cartesian product of [1..m] x [1..n]. We define f such that every element in the domain (x, y) gets mapped to x + y. Therefore, we know how to move from the domain to the codomain -- for any element you give me in the domain, I can easily tell you what element it gets mapped to in the codomain just by following this rule. Now, we have to think about going in the opposite direction, that is, given an element in the codomain, find some element in the domain which maps to it.

Since we want to find some element in the domain which maps to z, a reasonable first guess could be to let this element be (1, z - 1). Clearly, f(1, z-1) = 1 + z - 1 = z, so if this element (1, z-1) were to exist in the domain, it would indeed map to z as desired. However, the issue is that (1, z-1) doesn't always exist in the domain. Consider the case where z = m + n. Then, our element in the domain becomes (1, m + n - 1), which doesn't exist in the domain because m + n - 1 is not contained in the interval [1..n]. Remember that for any ordered pair in the domain, the first element needs to be in [1..m] while the second needs to be in [1..n] by definition of cartesian product.

Thus, the cases that we consider in the problem are necessary so that we can always ensure that the element we're providing actually exists in the domain. Consider the first case where 2 ≤ z ≤ m + 1. In this case, we can let our element in the domain be (z - 1, 1). Once again, we see that f(z - 1, 1) = z. However, because we now know that 2 ≤ z ≤ m + 1, or equivalently, 1 ≤ z - 1 ≤ m (subtracting 1 from all parts of the inequality), we guarantee that the first element of this ordered pair is within the desired range, as seen by the fact that z - 1 must be between 1 and m. Similar logic can be used for the second case as well to see that the element that's provided actually exists in the domain and maps to z. 

tldr: the cases are necessary to guarantee that the provided elements exist in the domain, and m + 1 just happens to be a convenient upper bound to choose for the first case

history.subject: Using WLOG for combinatorial proof
history.content: For 6b, I am trying to prove the left hand side by stating the problem as dividing r stars into m+1 bins, then choosing one arbitrary bin and adding the cases where there's 0 stars in the bin, 1 star in the bin... etc. Do I have to use WLOG here because I am arbitrarily selecting one bin to divide the cases?

WLOG is usually used for proving rather than counting. Also, you usually only use arbitrary if you are trying to prove a "for all" claim. For example, if I want to prove that $$A \subseteq B$$, then I let $$a \in A$$ be arbitrary and show that $$a \in B$$. Because $$a$$ was arbitrary, this proves the claim for all elements of $$A$$. Do you need this bin to be arbitrary here?

history.content:
Is this explanation sufficient for why any 4 vertices have 1 intersection point, or would I need to explain further?

"If we choose 2 points that are adjacent to each other within the 4 points, the other 2 points will also be adjacent to each other within the 4 points, and the 2 lines that are created will intersect outside the shape.

The only way to create 2 lines that intersect within the shape is to choose 2 points that are opposite each other within the 4 points (there is 1 point between them on either side), because then their lines will cross each other at 1 intersection point."

The converse is from the definition of a well-defined function in general. Namely, an element $$x$$ can only be mapped to one element $$f(x)$$.

history.content: Is it closed form to include X in our final answer for 2b?

$$x$$ is just a variable in this question, just like $$n$$ is. So yes, a closed form answer may include $$x$$, for the same reason why answers like $$n, n^2, n!$$ are considered close form. However, if you find you are using $$x$$ as a bound, like $$\sum_{i=1}^x i$$, then it is not closed form for the same reason an answer like $$\sum_{i=1}^n i$$ is not closed form.

Edit: my bad I misread the question. In this problem $$x$$ is not a variable, it is simply a way to express all elements in the domain. You should not use $$x$$ in your answer because it does not take on any concrete value.

history.subject: Self paced example question
history.content: In the self paced example for inverse function, I am confused about the part where we prove f is injective. How is the "using definition of inverse..." part proving the contrapositive? Can we say that g(f(x1)) = g(f(x2)) from f(x1) = f(x2) ?

The definition of injective is that for every x1, x2 in the domain, if x1 ≠ x2, then f(x1) ≠ f(x2). In other words, different inputs must map to different outputs. The contrapositive of this is for every x1, x2 in the domain, if f(x1) = f(x2), then x1 = x2. That's why in our proof, we start with f(x1) = f(x2), which means we can apply g to both sides because the LHS and RHS are assumed to be equal.

children.subject: Can we apply a function to both sides even if we do not know what the function does?
In this case, we do know what the function g does. It's the inverse function, which by definition satisfies g(f(x)) = x for any x in the domain
Thank you. Are there functions that we cannot apply to both sides on?

Yes. Consider g(x) = sqrt(x) and f(x) = x^2. If I know that f(x) = f(y), or in other words that x^2 = y^2, then I can't simply apply g on both sides to conclude that x = y. Consider the case when x = -2, y = 2 for instance. x^2 = y^2 is true because (-2)^2 = (2)^2, but x = y isn't true because -2 ≠ 2.

As it turns out, we can only apply g to both sides because f must be a bijective function in order for g, its inverse, to exist. This means that f is injective and therefore wouldn't map two different elements to the same output, which is the issue here since our f mapped both -2 and 2 to 4.

history.subject: HW Deadline
history.content:
Hey everyone,

Recently we’ve been receiving a number of requests to accept late HW. We just wanted to reiterate that we cannot accept late submissions under any circumstances. We give 2 HW drops (~20% of the HWs) in order to account for health, tech issues, busy schedules, etc. We strongly encourage students to keep these drops in hand so that when unexpected circumstances arise you are able to take a drop without affecting your grade. As for technical issues, it is your responsibility to submit your HW on time. If you wait until 11:50pm on Wednesday to submit your HW, you may not be able to submit on time. In the case where Gradescope (for whatever reason) is not working, you can email a pdf of your submission to cis1600@seas.upenn.edu before the HW deadline.

If you have a longer term health issue that may prevent you from submitting multiple HWs, please reach out to us and we can try to find a solution. We are unable to give extensions for one-off illnesses, as we need to release solutions for the entire class to review from.

As always, feel free to reach out to us if you have any concerns – but know that we have limited flexibility when it comes to accepting late HW (and that you should plan accordingly). In a class of 250 students, this is critical to ensure fairness across the class.

Best of luck as you begin studying for Midterm One,
CIS1600 Staff

history.subject: Floor ceiling pigeons contrapositive / Erdos contradiction
history.content:
I am still confused about logical statements. Here, if we take the contrapositive, why is the the latter half "the total number of objects is not equal to r"? If we negate "r objects are placed into n boxes", isn't it "r objects are not placed into n boxes"? How do we know that the number of objects is not equal to r?

Also, I am confused about how the above is the negation of "Every sequence of n^2+1 distinct integers must contain a monotone subsequence of length n+1". I guess negating long statements that are not explicitly stated in succinct notations is confusing. How can I improve on understanding this?

history.subject: Floor ceiling pigeons contrapositive
history.content: I am still confused about logical statements. Here, if we take the contrapositive, why is the the latter half "the total number of objects is not equal to r"? If we negate "r objects are placed into n boxes", isn't it "r objects are not placed into n boxes"? How do we know that the number of objects is not equal to r?

For the contrapositive statement, one way we can rewrite the original statement is "Assuming there are $$n$$ boxes, if $$r$$ objects are placed into those boxes, then there is at least one box containing at least $$\lceil \frac{r}{n} \rceil$$ objects," and then we could just take the contrapositive of the if–then part of this modified statement. When taking contrapositives, if there are multiple "premises" (i.e., multiple things connected with "and" on the left side of $$\implies$$), we can leave some of the premises intact and only reverse the direction of some of them (so for example, in this case, we can continue assuming $$n$$ and only flip the thing about $$r$$ objects). Another way to look at this is that if we flipped everything (i.e., written the latter half as "the total number of objects is not $$r$$ or the number of boxes is not $$n$$"), we would be able to create cases: case 1 being the number of boxes not being $$n$$, and case 2 being where we prove the contrapositive statement in the screenshot.

For the statement, "Every sequence of $$n^2+1$$ distinct integers must contain a monotone subsequence of length $$n+1$$," let's first rewrite this using quantifiers: "For all sequences of $$n^2+1$$ distinct integers, there exists some monotone subsequence of the original sequence of length $$n+1$$." Then, remembering that we negate quantifiers by changing "there exists" into "for all" and vice versa and negating the inside as well, the negation of this statement is "There exists some sequence of $$n^2+1$$ distinct integers such that for all monotone subsequences of that sequence, the length of the subsequence is at most $$n$$." In this case, in our contradiction assumption there is an implicit "there exists some sequence of $$n^2+1$$" that we do not include, and I think that might have been a little confusing.

I hope these explanations help! Feel free to ask if you have any more questions.

history.subject: Module 6.2
history.content: How do we get to 2k + 1 <= 2^k ? Shouldn't the LHS be k^2 + 2k + 1, why did we get rid of the k^2?

We want to prove that k^2 + 2k + 1 < 2^(k + 1), but this is equivalent to showing that k^2 + 2k + 1 < 2^k + 2^k. If we look at the bolded terms, we notice that we can apply IH to conclude that k^2 < 2^k, so if we remove these terms from the inequality, we see that we just have to show that 2k + 1 <= 2^k for the entire inequality to hold. A justification for this is given later on in the slides
You invoke the IH, which says that $$k^2 < 2^k$$. You must invoke the induction hypothesis in the induction step to create a valid induction proof.

history.subject: I'm confused as to why it says that the pigeon rule is the contrapositive of injection?

history.content: The injection rule is that if a function is injective, |A| ≤ |B| where A is the domain and B is the codomain. The contrapositive of this statement is that if |A| > |B|, then the function isn't injective, which is the same as what PHP states.

children.subject: But doesn’t the contrapositive have to be an equivalent statement to the original statement?

Yes, the contrapositive of the injective rule is that if |A| > |B|, the function is not injective, that is there exists some element in the codomain that has multiple elements mapped to it, this is equivalent to the pigenhole principle since you can treat the domain as the pigeons and the codomain as the holes

history.content:
Let's use the notation from module 2.7 slide 3.

You would actually write this as $$\forall n, integer(n) \land oddfactor(n)$$. In which case, the negation would be $$\exists n, \neg \left( integer(n) \land oddfactor(n) \right) = \exists n, \neg integer(n) \lor \neg oddfactor(n)$$.

Let's check by trying to reason about it. This statement is referring to all positive integers with an odd number of factors. So what number would not be included? Well, first would be any number that is a positive integer but has even number of factors. This is represented by $$\neg oddfactor(n)$$. It can also be a number that is not a positive integer, which is represented by $$\neg integer(n)$$.

history.subject: 4.4 example?
history.content: I don't really understand what example 1,2  means - is there a more concrete explanation/example for this? Also, what is g(f) and h(f) for the question below?

g and h are examples of functions that have the domain $$B^A$$ and codomain $$2^C$$. So the domain of g and h are functions and the codomain of g and h are subsets of [1..n].

A good question is what is the size of the domain? And what is the size of the codomain? 

The domain has size $$n^n$$ and the codomain has size $$2^n$$. 

To understand the function $$g$$, consider an arbitrary function $$\phi: [1..n] \rightarrow [1..n]$$. Note that $$\phi \in [1..n]^{[1..n]}$$, so it is in the domain. Note that $$\phi$$ takes as input $$x \in [1..n]$$ and outputs some $$y \in [1..n]$$. That is, $$\phi(x) = y$$ where $$x, y \in [1..n]$$.

When evaluating $$g(\phi)$$, we note that the mapping is defined by $$\{x | f(x) = 1\}$$ where $$x \in [1..n]$$. Therefore, the mapping is looking at all elements of $$[1..n]$$ such that when $$\phi$$ acts on that element, the output is $$1$$. These elements form a subset of $$[1..n]$$. How exciting! Let's call this subset $$A$$. That is, we have $$A \subseteq [1..n]$$ and $$\forall a \in A$$, we have $$\phi(a) = 1$$. 

Then, $$g(\phi) = A$$.

For function $$h$$, we do something similar, but now $$h$$ maps $$\phi$$ to its range (which is also a subset of $$[1..n]$$). 

For the last part of the question, we are given $$f$$ as the identity function. This means, $$\forall x \in [1..n]$$ we have $$f(x) = x$$. We want to compute $$g(f)$$. This is equivalent to asking: "What is the set $$A \subseteq [1..n]$$ such that $$\forall a \in A$$ we have $$f(a) = 1$$?". Well, if $$f$$ is the identity, then it must be that $$A = \{1\}$$. Therefore, $$g(f) = \{1\}$$.

For $$h(f)$$ we ask ourselves, "if $$f$$ is the identity function, what is $$Ran(f)$$?". Well, this is just $$[1..n]$$. So, we have $$h(f) = [1..n]$$

history.subject: Midterm Qs 19 and 29
history.content: What is the difference between Q19 and Q29 that makes us use complementary counting for 19 and direct method for 29? If you use similar logic in Q19 that you do in Q29, you get different answers?

The biggest distinction is that, in Q29, we're explicitly labeling two of the TA's that get more than 2 papers as "Head TAs". If we look at a small example, we can see why this changes our answer. 

Consider the case where we have 10 indistinguishable objects that we're distributing among 4 distinguishable bins. There are two variants of this question that we can ask: 

1. How many ways are there to distribute these 10 indistinguishable objects into the 4 distinguishable bins such that at least two of the bins have at least two objects, and every bin has at least one? (Q19)

In this counting question, for example, the distribution of: 

1 | 3 | 3 | 3 

would count as exactly one valid distribution. 

2. How many ways are there to distribute these 10 indistinguishable objects into the 4 distinguishable bins such that two of these bins are labelled as "Head Bins" and must have at least two objects, and every other bin has at least one? (Q29) 

In this variant, the exact same distribution of 1 | 3 | 3 | 3 would need to be counted 3 times, since we can choose any two of the groups of 3 as "Head Bins," and designating different bins as Heads counts as a different distribution. 

You can see how these are different problems because of that added caveat, and if you test out the expressions we get with our different counting methods, you'll notice that the number of ways to do Q29 is larger than the number of ways to do Q19 because of this.

history.subject: Derangements self paced exercise formula derivation
history.content:
Screen_Shot_2023-02-13_at_9.37.20_AM

What is the set J? Is this the set that we're finding the intersections for when we're counting using PIE? Also, can you explain the RHS - why are we placing elements in the other n-k positions?

J is just an arbitrary subset of $$[1..n]$$. It basically narrows down which values we are focusing on (of whether or not they are in the right position) in the permutation. 

For the RHS, recall that elements of $$\bigcap_{j \in J} B_j$$ will be those permutations such that the elements of $$j$$ are in the right position. So we can compute the cardinality of this via a procedure where in the first step, we fix the elements of $$J$$ in their correct position (of which there are $$k$$ elements) and then we permute the remaining elements. The first step occurs in just 1 way, and the second step occurs in $$(n-k)!$$ ways.

history.subject: Set proof of empty set?
history.content:
I was doing some practice questions I found online and one was about proving that some set operations equaled the empty set.

In this class, we learned double inclusion to prove equality between two sets, but I figure you can't do that for empty sets because there is no abp element of an empty set.

So how would we approach proving this rigorously? Just show that the operations limit the scope of the set to nothing?

I suppose you could do the normal double inclusion method. Suppose you were asked to prove $$LHS = \emptyset$$. You could go about showing $$LHS \subseteq \emptyset$$ by considering an arbitrary element of the LHS and reach some sort of verdict based on that. And then when you show $$\emptyset \subseteq LHS$$, you would not have to consider an arbitrary element, because $$\emptyset \subseteq A$$ for any set $$A$$. So this side would just follow as fact.

history.subject: Understanding 5.sp1
history.content: I was wondering for 5sp1, for the proof of the claim that if f has an inverse, it is a bijection, to prove that f is injective they set f(x1) = f(x2) as usual for injectivity, however, then it seems that the example applies g to both sides, rpoducing g(f(x1)) = g(f(x2)), which of course means that x1 = x2. My confusion was whether we are allowed to apply  g to both sides, without having proved yet that the function g is bijective?

Functions in general always map every input to a unique output. We know that since f(x1) = f(x2), both f(x1) and f(x2) represent the same input to the function g, and therefore, must have the same output as well. Thus, it's valid to apply g to both sides simply because g is a function. Note however that even though we can always apply a function to both sides of an equality, it's the fact that g is an inverse which then allows us to conclude that x1 = x2.

Since functions always map every input to a unique output, we know that since f(x1) = f(x2), both f(x1) and f(x2) represent the same input to the function g, and therefore, must have the same output as well. Thus, it's valid to apply g to both sides simply because g is a function. history.content: If they are just using stars and bars, how are they accounting for the fact that all the net worth has to be unique (or stars in the buckets)

Remember that each star represents a donation of $3, and for every star in a particular bucket (or in other words, every $3 donation in a particular pair of individuals), we make the lower net worth person donate $1 and the higher net worth person donate $2. This accounts for the differences in net worth amongst individuals in a pair because we specify who has to donate each part of the overall $3 donation.

history.subject: HW2 5c
history.content:
Screen_Shot_2023-02-14_at_10.34.13_AM

Why does $x otin T \cup R$ imply $x otin T$ and $x ot R$. Is this an application of De Morgan's?
Yes. $$x otin T \cup R \implies eg (x \in T \cup R) \implies eg (x \in T \lor x \in R) \implies x otin T \land x otin R$$
yes

history.subject: Boundary of variable when proving
history.content: For example, when we are proving sqrt 6 is irrational, when we assume that sqrt 6 = a/b, there is no mention about what a and b are (integers, etc) in the solution. it is perfectly acceptable to write $$\sqrt{6} = \frac{a}{b}$$ where $$a, b \in \mathbb{Z}$$ and $$b \neq 0$$ and $$a, b$$ are relatively prime.

history.subject: When writing any sort of proof with statements (ex: set proofs)
history.content: Do we have to use 3 lines and say "logically equivalent" and not =? Is it wrong to say ... is the same as ... ?

I'm not sure what you mean by 3 lines.

Logically equivalent and "=" mean different things. For example, a truth table question might require logically equivalent whereas a set proof might require "=".

Saying ... is the same as ... is usually fine unless we ask specifically if two things are logically equivalent or if two things are equal, in which case you should answer accordingly rather than use "the same as."

children.subject: I meant three lines as the equal sign but with one more line on it. So for set proofs, even if x \in Z is a statement we use = instead of the "logically equivalent" sign?

Logically equivalent means the truth values are the same. "=" means the algebraic values are the same. They are not interchangeable, and their use really depends on the context.

I mentioned set proofs because if you were proving something like $$A = B$$, you are proving the sets are equal, not that the sets are logically equivalent.
So then is x \in A\B = x \in A and x \notin B or do these have to be logically equivalent?
Yeah these should be logically equivalent rather than just equals.

The anagram method would apply if we were arranging all 9 letters (and hence, will always have 5 indistinguishable a's). In this case you are only choosing 3 of them, so the number of a's you choose could vary from 0 to 3. This suggests that dividing by 5! would not apply.

history.subject: M1Q22/Logical consequence
history.content: What is the difference between saying something is a logical consequence and saying two things are logically equivalent?

Logical consequence was not covered in this class, but in this question it is defined as: $$e_2$$ is a logical consequence of $$e_1$$ if every truth assignment that makes $$e_1$$ true also makes $$e_2$$ true. Note the difference between this and logically equivalent is that we don't care about when $$e_1$$ is false for logical consequence, but in logical equivalence, values that makes $$e_1$$ false will also have to make $$e_2$$ false.

history.content: When I was first doing this problem, I used multiplication rule. For step 1 I had the first player choose a hat, which can be done in 3 ways. In your counting procedure, step one could choose $$r_1$$ and step 2 could choose $$r_2$$, or they could be flipped and step one could choose $$r_2$$ and step 2 could choose $$r_1$$. Your counting procedure would count these differently.

history.subject: M1 Q1
history.content: When a = 1, b = n - 1 = 1, so this case is when b=a, not when a < b. I don't believe there is a case where a  < b. Can we just read statements like these as b=a? When $$k = 1$$, we have $$a = 1$$ and $$b = n-1$$. But it is not the case that $$b = n-1 = 1$$. We can say that $$b = n - 1 \geq 1$$ because this comes from $$n \geq 2$$.

history.subject: Q36
history.content: For 36, can you explain how we can remove the ordering of certain things (in this case amongst pairs and within pairs) by simply dividing? I thought we accounted for bad cases by subtracting them using complementary counting.

Ok let's try simplifying the question to just be 6 people. Our smaller question will just be how to put them into 3 groups of 2, where the order of the groups does not matter and the order of the people within a group also does not matter.

There are 2 ways to answer this question. Perhaps the more intuitive way is just to use the "choose" notation.

Step 1. Choose 2 people from 6 - $$\binom{6}{2}$$

Step 2. Choose 2 people from 4 - $$\binom{4}{2}$$

Step 3. Choose 2 people from 2 - $$\binom{2}{2}$$

Now note that this makes sure the people within the group are not ordered, but there is an order to the groups. Let's give names to these people to verify this. Say they are $$p_1, p_2, p_3, p_4, p_5, p_6$$.

Step 1 could choose $$p_1, p_2$$, step 2 could choose $$p_3, p_4$$, and step 3 could choose $$p_5, p_6$$. But we could get the exact same grouping if step 1 chose $$p_3, p_4$$, step 2 chose $$p_1, p_2$$ and step 3 chose $$p_5, p_6$$. These would create the same groups but count as different based on our counting procedure. We need to divide out the order of the groups. The final answer is $$\binom{6}{2} \binom{4}{2} \binom{2}{2} / 3!$$.

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

There's another way to count this. We first permute all the people $$6!$$. Now we'll call each consecutive pair as one group. Note that we run into the same issue as the counting procedure above, so we need to divide by $$3!$$. But now our procedure also makes the people within the group's order matter. For example $$p_1 p_2 p_3 p_4 p_5 p_6$$ would be the same groupings as $$p_2 p_1 p_3 p_4 p_5 p_6$$ but our procedure counts them as different. So for each pair, we need to divide out by 2. So our final answer is $$\frac{6!}{3! \cdot 2 \cdot 2 \cdot 2} = \frac{6!}{3! 2^3}$$.

Ok let's try simplifying the question to just be 6 people. Our smaller question will just be how to put them into 3 groups of 2, where the order of the groups does not matter and the order of the people within a group also does not matter.

There are 2 ways to answer this question. Perhaps the more intuitive way is just to use the "choose" notation.

Step 1. Choose 2 people from 6 - $$\binom{6}{2}$$

Step 2. Choose 2 people from 4 - $$\binom{4}{2}$$

Step 3. Choose 2 people from 2 - $$\binom{2}{2}$$

Now note that this makes sure the people within the group are not ordered, but there is an order to the groups. Let's give names to these people to verify this. Say they are $$p_1, p_2, p_3, p_4, p_5, p_6$$.

Step 1 could choose $$p_1, p_2$$, step 2 could choose $$p_3, p_4$$, and step 3 could choose $$p_5, p_6$$. But we could get the exact same grouping if step 1 chose $$p_3, p_4$$, step 2 chose $$p_1, p_2$$ and step 3 chose $$p_5, p_6$$. These would create the same groups but count as different based on our counting procedure. We need to divide out the order of the groups. The final answer is $$\binom{6}{2} \binom{4}{2} \binom{2}{2} / 3!$$.

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

There's another way to count this. We first permute all the people $$6!$$. Now we'll call each consecutive pair as one group. Note that we run into the same issue as the counting procedure above, so we need to divide by $$3!$$. But now our procedure also makes the people within the group's order matter. For example $$p_1 p_2 p_3 p_4 p_5 p_6$$ would be the same groupings as $$p_2 p_1 p_3 p_4 p_5 p_6$$ but our procedure counts them as different. So for each pair, we need to divide out by 2. So our final answer is $$\frac{6!}{3! \cdot 2 \cdot 2 \cdot 2} = \frac{6!}{3! 2^3}$$.

history.subject: Definition of R,Z,N?
history.content: What's our definition of real numbers, natural numbers, and integers?

history.subject: Definition of R,Z,N?
history.content: What's are definition of real numbers, natural numbers, and integers?

$$\mathbb{N} = \{0, 1, 2, 3, ... \}$$. It is the set of all counting, whole numbers starting from 0.

$$\mathbb{Z} = \{... -2, -1, 0, 1, 2, ... \}$$. It is the set of all counting, whole numbers.

$$\mathbb{R}$$ contains all positive or negative whole numbers, fractions or decimals. 

This yields the following relationships: $$\mathbb{N} \subseteq \mathbb{Z}$$, $$\mathbb{N} \subseteq \mathbb{R}$$, $$\mathbb{Z} \subseteq \mathbb{R}$$

history.subject: Midterm 1 39d
history.content: How did we get that there are (99 choose 39) sets containing 40 and (99 choose 40) sets not containing 40?

Consider sets of size 40 that contain the element 40.

Step 1. Choose 40 to be an element in your set - 1 way

Step 2. There are 99 elements left. Choose the other 39 elements in your set - $$\binom{99}{39}$$

Consider sets of size 40 that do not contain the element 40.

history.subject: Disjoint vs Pairwise Disjoint
history.content: Are these two different definitions? If so, can you explain the difference?

Two sets are said to be disjoint if they share no elements in common. That is, $$A$$ and $$B$$ are disjoint when $$A \cap B = \emptyset$$. The term "pairwise disjoint" has a definition that builds off the definition of "disjoint". We say a collection of sets $$A_1, A_2, ..., A_n$$ are pairwise disjoint when $$\forall i, j$$, we have $$A_i \cap A_j = \emptyset$$.

children.subject: So all of the sets have no elements in common?

history.subject: midterm practice Q24 contrapositive
history.content: I am confused about the contrapositive way of proving this. Since there is a case that does not make sense, namely when n^2-1 = 4k+2 , how is it that the contrapositive still works? I think there was something like this also mentioned in the interactive session.

the contrapositive is "if $$n^2-1$$ is not a multiple of 4 then n is even". so to prove this, we consider the cases when $$n^2-1$$ is odd and when it is even. correct me if i'm wrong, but i think the case you are confused about is when $$n^2-1$$ is even? in this case, $$n^2$$ must be odd, so n must be odd (can express as $$2k+1$$)

then, we can write $$n^2-1$$ as $$(2k+1)^2-1$$ and when we expand this out, we see that this always is a multiple of 4. but our original assumption was that $$n^2-1$$ was not a multiple of 4, so this case is impossible! i.e. $$n^2-1$$ can never be even if $$n^2-1$$ is not to be a multiple of 4.

history.subject: quantifiers
history.content:
Why is the forall quantifier connected with "implies" while exists is connected with "and"?

]

Edit: sorry it is correct that for all should have an implication sign whereas exists should have an "and" sign.

We can think of examples for both cases. Let's consider the claim "all integers are rational numbers." Then P(x) is the claim "x is a rational number." Then $$\forall x \in \mathbb{Z}, P(x) \equiv \forall x, x \in \mathbb{Z} \implies x$$ is a rational number. If you were to prove this, you have to consider an arbitrary integer and then show it is a rational number.

Let's consider the claim "there is some integer that is even." Then P(x) is the claim "x is even." Then $$\exists x \in \mathbb{Z}, P(x) \equiv \exists x, x \in \mathbb{Z} \land x$$ is even. There's no implication here, since knowing x is an integer would not imply it is even. Rather, the statement is just saying there is an integer x that is also even.
The "implies" should be an "and".

history.subject: Function Question
history.content:
Can there be a function with an empty domain? If so, would it be considered injective?

And can there be a function with an empty codomain?

I think functions can have empty domains, and if a function has an empty domain, then it is vacuously injective.

If a function has an empty codomain, then the domain must also be empty. This is because each element of the domain must be mapped to some element of the codomain, which is vacuously true when the domain is empty, but when the domain is nonempty, then there is nothing for the elements to map to.

Number of ways of distributing n stars into r bins where at least one empty bin have to be empty?

binom(n+r-2)(r-2)

Is it also possible to do complimentary counting and get binom(n+r-1)(r-1) - binom(n-1)(r-1) where we subtract cases where all bins have at least one object inside? 

Also, is the number of ways where there is no empty bins the same as first distributing 1 star to each bin and then using stars and bars?

These wouldn't be the same, since the bins in stars and bars are distinguishable. Thus, you would technically need to first choose the bin to be empty ($$n$$ ways) (but then, we have issues with overcounting, since multiple bins could be empty and they could be counted multiple times).

Complementary counting would be the way to go here.

history.subject: Practice Question 21 (a)
history.content: Since sets do not double count the case in which the two same hats are chosen in different orders and we can say there are 6 hats to choose from (2 red, 2 blue, 2 green), why doesn't $$\binom{6}{2}^{12}$$ work? And how does $$6^{12}$$ work given MR since each player would be choosing 1 of 6 hats?

$$\binom{6}{2}$$ does not work because this would be choosing 2 hats from 6 completely distinguishable hats. In this case, while different colored hats are distinguishable, same colored hats are indistinguishable.

The $$6^{12}$$ is not saying each player chooses 1 of the 6 hats, it is saying each player has 6 total options for how they can choose 2 hats. We can in fact list these options out:

  1. red red
  2. red blue
  3. red green
  4. blue blue
  5. blue green
  6. green green
