history.subject: Apply to be a CIS 1600 TA!
history.content:
Hi everyone!

Applications to be a CIS TA for 1100, 1200, 1600 or 1210 are now available at: https://forms.gle/D6VphTavVSMtetBN9

Applications are due Tuesday, April 11th at 11:59pm, and interviews will take place soon after. There are no prerequisites to be a TA, other than a zeal for teaching! You do not need to have taken the course you are applying for, although it helps. You also do not need to be a CIS or Engineering major; our students come from all over the University, and our TAs do too! As a TA, your duties may include leading weekly recitation, grading weekly homework assignments, holding office hours, and attending a weekly staff meeting. New TAs may also be required to attend a weekly TA training on Fridays.

  • Note that you must fill out the CIS 1600 supplemental application if you wish to be considered. You should receive email confirmation that your supplement was successfully submitted.

We’ll be having a TA Application Panel for students to ask about the TA experience Wednesday April 5 from 7-8:30pm in Wu & Chen Auditorium. We will also be answering questions about what we look for in the application and interview process. Hope to see you there! If you have any additional questions about what it’s like to be a TA, feel free to reach out to anyone on the course staff. We would love to read your application!

history.subject: Rubric error for HW6 Q1
history.content: Before midterm, I asked about HW6 Q1 in office hours about the base case. Apparently the equation still holds when the power is -1 so the TAs said my proof is also valid. I think it was Darren and Sydney who were in the office hour. I know the regrade deadline's passed but will it be possible to get points back since this is also valid? Thank you.
You say by IH but when k = 0 you cannot apply your IH to k-1.

children.subject: Krish is right, I overlooked the fact that you cited IH to say that that was an integer. Apologies for the mistake!
I am confused by what that means - can I not apply it because I define the bound as greater than equal to 0?
But then if I define k as greater than or equal to 1, then k-1 = 0 so isn't it still outside the bound of k?
You handle the k-1=0 case via your base case, which you've proven separately to be an integer. In your IS, you're allowed to assume your base case holds since you've already proven it
Your IH assumes it is true for all integers $$j$$, where $$0 \le j \le k$$. This allows you to apply IH for $$x^0 + \frac{1}{x^0}$$.
Then for my solution to work should I have written a base case for n = -1?
Yes, it would work but you would end up having two base cases $$n=-1$$ and $$n=0$$. In brief, you need two base cases for this problem regardless of whether you start at -1 or at 0.

history.subject: Issue with Homework 9
history.content:
We made a mistake and when we reposted the homework to fix something minor, we included the solutions too! We were alerted to this by many wonderful students among you, and we thank them.

So now, the instructor, that’s me, Val, has to make a decision what to do with this homework. Working on this problems is going to be very very useful for you all as you prepare for the final exam. The final is cumulative  but graph theory problems will constitute most of its content. That’s why I do not want to take the easy way out (for me) and just cancel this homework.

While I am persuaded that that best thing students could do for their preparation is to ignore the solutions if they accessed them, some possibly will not. Others, who did not access the solutions, will feel that those who did have an unfair advantage.

So we will continue with this homework and we will grade it very carefully. The students whose submitted solutions appear to be copied from those we published will not be able to use the score of this homework to improve their average. This homework simply will not count for them (we still drop their two lowest).

(If you worry about how we can tell, it’s the same as when we see common solutions among students.)

What to do to avoid this as you submit this homework. If you do not have the solutions, nothing. Including not trying to procure them from another student who might have them. If you have the solutions, don’t read them (I know, I know, easy for me to say it…)

I am very sorry to add these concerns to your work in this course. Please believe me that I am only thinking of the benefits for the students and  the fairness involved.

Val

history.subject: 12.2 Question in video
history.content:
The question in the video is:

How many cycles of length 4 are there in $$~K_4$$?

How is the correct answer of 15 obtained?

Let $$K_5 = (V, E)$$ where $$V = \{v_1, v_2, v_3, v_4, v_5\}$$ and $$(v_i, v_j) \in E \quad \forall i, j$$.

Step 1: Choose 4 vertices. This can be done in $$\binom{5}{4}$$ ways.

Suppose, WLOG, the vertices we chose were $$v_1, v_2, v_3, v_4$$. 

Step 2: Create a cycle out of them. We can do this in three ways:

1. $$v_1 - v_2 - v_3 - v_4$$

2. $$v_1 - v_3 - v_2 - v_4$$

3. $$v_1 - v_3 - v_4 - v_2 $$.

By MR, we have: $$\binom{5}{4} \cdot 3 = 15$$

Let $$K_4 = (V, E)$$ where $$V = \{v_1, v_2, v_3, v_4, v_5\}$$ and $$(v_i, v_j) \in E \quad \forall i, j$$.

Step 1: Choose 4 vertices. This can be done in $$\binom{5}{4}$$ ways.

Suppose, WLOG, the vertices we chose were $$v_1, v_2, v_3, v_4$$. 

Step 2: Create a cycle out of them. We can do this in three ways:

1. $$v_1 - v_2 - v_3 - v_4$$

2. $$v_1 - v_3 - v_2 - v_4$$

3. $$v_1 - v_3 - v_4 - v_2 $$.

By MR, we have: $$\binom{5}{4} \cdot 3 = 15$$

history.subject: Wording on Q3
history.content:
"Prove that there exists 2 distinct pairs of bunnies that do not have a partnership with each other."

Does this mean, prove we can find distinct bunnies A, B, C, and D such that A and B are partners and C and D are partners, but A/B isn't partners with either C or D.

It means to find two distinct pairs of bunnies $$(a, b)$$ and $$(c, d)$$ such that $$a$$ isn't partners with $$b$$ and $$c$$ isn't partners with $$d$$. Note that $$a, b, c, d$$ do not have to all be distinct

children.subject: so can bunnies A not be parters with B and A cant be partners with C and that would count as 2 pairs?

Yes, that would count as 2 distinct pairs.

Basically there's a difference between disjoint and distinct. Disjoint means they cannot share any elements in common. Distinct means they cannot have exactly the same elements. In this case, we want distinct pairs.

history.subject: existence proof
history.content:
Are we allowed to use both constructive and non-constructive proof for existence?

Existence proofs: To prove a statement of the form ∃x ∈ S,P(x), we give either a constructive or a non-contructive proof. In a constructive proof, one proves the statement by exhibiting a specific x ∈ S such that P(x) is true. In a non-constructive proof, one proves the statement using an indirect proof such as a proof by contradiction. Thus, one might prove that the negation ∀x ∈ S,∼ P(x) is false by deriving a contradiction.
Yes -Ishaan

history.subject: Theorem about clique and independent set
history.content:
we know the theorem ( S is a clique of G iff S is an independent set of ~G).
Can this go the other way around by switching G? (S is a clique of ~G iff S is an independent set of G) ? Do we have to prove that or can we just use it?

you can go the other way. This is because in the theorem, $$G$$ is just an arbitrary graph. We can rewrite the theorem in an equivalent way as: "$$S$$ is a clique of a graph iff $$S$$ is an independent set of the complement of the graph".

In this way, we see the arbitrary-ness of the graph!

history.subject: Q6
history.content: If I'm attempting to prove $\kappa(G) \leq \chi(G)$ and have already proven both that kappa can't be larger than the chromatic number and they can be equal, is it enough to provide an example of a graph where the chromatic number is larger than kappa? Like add in a diagram? Thanks!

So say you want to prove $$\kappa(G) \le \chi(G)$$ is the most restrictive bound. If you have proven for all $$G$$, $$\kappa(G) ot > \chi(G)$$, then so far you have proven $$\kappa(G) \le \chi(G)$$ is a bound (but not necessarily most restrictive). The possible bounds at this point are $$\kappa(G) \le \chi(G)$$, $$\kappa(G) < \chi(G)$$, and $$\kappa(G) = \chi(G)$$.

Now to prove it is the most restrictive bound, you would want to show the other two bounds do not always hold. Thus, you should show $$\exists G, \kappa(G) ot < \chi(G)$$ as well as $$\exists G, \kappa(G) e \chi(G)$$.

history.subject: Q6 : proof by contradiction
history.content: as an example, if we want to show a < b then can we assume for the sake of contradiction that a >= b and then show the contradiction to complete the proof? or does that assume what we're trying to prove and make the proof pattern invalid?

I suppose it depends on how you do the contradiction proof.

Let's consider q6a. If you want to show $$\forall G, \alpha(G) < \kappa(G)$$, you would assume for contradiction that $$\exists G, \alpha(G) \ge \kappa(G)$$. An incorrect way to do this is to then show a counterexample where $$\alpha(G) \not \ge \kappa(G)$$. This doesn't reach a contradiction because we only assumed there exists a $$G$$ where $$\alpha(G) \ge \kappa(G)$$. As long as you reach a proper contradiction, then this would be a valid way to go about this problem.

When it says: "There exists a directed pathway between platforms such that if a student starts on one platform, they can eventually move to every other platform, visiting each platform exactly once."

history.subject: q6 how does induction work
history.content: for the induction step, if we want to show that a claim holds for a full binary tree of height k+1, do we need to start with the tree of height k+1, or can we start with a height of k (and then add vertices to get to a height k+1)?

Usually in graph induction, you should start with the $$k+1$$ case, reduce it down to the $$k$$ case, and then build back up to the $$k+1$$ case.

This is because when starting from $$k$$ and going to $$k+1$$ directly, we may not consider every single graph that has $$k+1$$ things.

history.subject: HW11 Q6 question
history.content: I don't understand why b is necessary. If we show that any full binary tree of height h has 2h+1 or more nodes, isn't it impossible to have 2h nodes anyways?

If you show $$ u(h) \ge 2h+1$$, then it is impossible to only have $$2h$$ nodes. But this isn't what the statement is saying. The statement is saying that to prove something is the minimum, you need to prove it is both a lower bound and that it is a strict lower bound. Part (a) proves it is a lower bound, and part (b) proves it is strict.

For example, if you only proved part (a), that is $$ u(h) \ge 2h+1$$, how do we know this is the actual minimum? An easy way to see why this could be abused is if we instead showed $$ u(h) \ge 0$$. 0 is definitely not the minimum number of nodes in a full binary tree of height $$h$$, but this statement $$ u(h) \ge 0$$ is still true. Only proving $$ u(h) \ge x$$ will not be sufficient to show $$x$$ is the minimum number of nodes, you also have to show that $$x$$ is achievable for arbitrary values of $$h$$.

history.subject: induction with graphs
history.content: how do we know whether we should induct on vertices or edges?

What you induct on really depends on the problem. Also, both induction on edges and induction on vertices have their own separate issues, so it just depends.

For example, inducting on vertices can sometimes be annoying because when you remove a vertex, you also have to remove all incident edges. But at the same time, inducting on vertices can be nice when you can guarantee existence of a specific type of vertex in a graph (i.e a leaf in a tree)

What's nice about edge induction is that when you remove an edge, you don't have to remove any vertices, but removing edges can disconnect the graph, and removing edges in general may not be as easy to generalize as removing vertices.

history.subject: HW11 Q3 question
history.content: This problem says that we need show t that G is connected and acyclic. I was wondering why we have to rigorously prove this given that the graph is DAG. I thought since we already know that it is DAG, we know it is acyclic and connected, so there is no need to prove they are connected and acyclic.

You are given a DAG $$G$$. This means $$G$$ is a directed graph with no directed cycles. Furthermore, we know that a source $$t$$ in $$G$$ has a unique directed path to every vertex $$v$$.

You then change all the directed edges into undirected edges and then have to prove this new undirected graph is connected and acyclic. This is now a completely new graph as the old one was directed and this one is now undirected. So now you have to prove this new undirected graph is connected and has no undirected cycles.

history.subject: HW11, Q6
history.content: In the first part of the proof, when we delete at least 2 nodes, why don't we consider the case of bringing these nodes back? same for the second part, when we add, why we don't remove it after it?

We can equivalently re-write the solution as follows:

"The resulting tree, call it $$T'$$ has height $$k$$. By the IH, $$T'$$ has $$\geq 2k + 1$$ nodes. Since we removed $$\geq 2$$ nodes, our original tree $$T$$ by re-introducing the nodes we removed, has $$\geq (2k + 1) + 2 = 2(k+1) + 1$$ nodes."

For the second part of the proof, we are starting from the $$k$$ case and building up to the $$k+1$$ case, so there is no need to remove the nodes.

history.subject: Isomorphism
history.content: What is the standard of isomorphism? If you can flip, stretch, and manipulate the graph just that we don't break or add new edges, is it okay?

That is the correct intuition of an isomorphism is. Formally, two graphs $$G = (V, E)$$ and $$G' = (V', E')$$ are isomorphic if there exists a bijection $$\phi: V \mapsto V'$$ such that $$\forall (u, v) \in E$$, we have $$(\phi(u), \phi(v)) \in E'$$

history.subject: Isomorphism and colorability
history.content: Here, aren't the two instances the same if you rotate one? For colorability, do you assume that there is no isomorphism?

You do not consider isomorphisms with colorings, because a coloring is defined to be a function $$f: V \mapsto \{1, \ldots k\}$$. So having vertex $$a$$ colored with color $$2$$, for example, would be different from vertex $$a$$ being colored with color $$1$$.

history.subject: Probability Review Session Follow Up
history.content:
To those that attended my review session earlier today, here's an example when events are pairwise independent but not mutually independent.

We roll 2 dice, and let:

A = event the sum of the die is odd (Pr(A) = 1/2)

B = event the first dice is even (Pr(B) = 1/2)

C - event the second dice is even (Pr(C) = 1/2)

If we work out the probabilities, we see that the A, B and C are all pairwise independent.

However, Pr(A∩B∩C) = 0, which is not the same as Pr(A) x Pr(B) x Pr(C).

Also note that mutual independence implies pairwise independence, but not vice versa.

Best of luck!

history.subject: Confused how the complement of a path can be the same as the path

history.content:
This only works for $$P_4$$. You should try drawing it out and seeing the bijection. If $$P_4$$ is the graph $$V = \{v_1, v_2, v_3, v_4\}$$ and $$E = \{(v_1, v_2), (v_2, v_3), (v_3, v_4)\}$$, then the complement is the graph with vertex set $$V' = \{v_1, v_2, v_3, v_4\}$$ and edges $$E' = \{(v_1, v_3), (v_1, v_4), (v_2, v_4)\}$$.

The bijection $$\phi: V \mapsto V'$$ is defined by $$\phi(v_1) = v_2$$, $$\phi(v_2) = v_4$$, $$\phi(v_3) = v_1$$ and $$\phi(v_4) = v_3$$

history.subject: edge and cycle
history.content:
In a tree $$G=(V,E)$$ (undirected), adding one more edge will result in a cycle, by the minimally acyclic property (and hopefully we don't have to prove this on the final...?). Following this logic, do we know that with each edge we add, the number of cycles in $$G$$ will increase by exactly 1? If so, do we have to prove it, and how might we approach this proof?

Related, if a connected undirected graph with $$n$$ vertices has exactly $$k$$ cycles, does such a graph have exactly $$k$$ extra edges compared to its spanning tree?

This question is inspired by Final Review Q11 for reference

It is NOT true that with each edge we add, the number of cycles in $$G$$ will increase by exactly 1. Take, for example, $$G = (V, E)$$ with $$V = \{v_1, v_2, v_3, v_4\}$$ and $$E = \{(v_1, v_2), (v_2, v_3), (v_3, v_4)$$. This graph is a tree with zero cycles. Adding the edge $$(v_4, v_1)$$ creates a single cycle. However, if we were to add another edge (while still including $$(v_4, v_1)$$), say $$(v_1, v_3)$$, then the resulting graph has $$3$$ cycles.

It follows that the answer to your "related" question is no.

children.subject: Then do we have that "in an undirected tree, with each edge we add, there will be at least 1 new cycle formed"?
I believe so

history.subject: final problems q5
history.content: why does every vertex have to have a minimum degree of n-2? I don't quite understand the answer key explanation. How do we know the two non-adjacent vertices are not also v's?

I think the solution started off like this from an intuition. Imagine some graph, and no matter which three vertices you pick out they are always linked in the fashion described, then it must be that every vertex has some high degrees.

The second intuition is, $$\frac{n^2}{2} -n$$ looks very sus, so why not manipulate it a bit, and we get $$\frac{n^2}{2} -\frac{2n}{2} = \frac{n^2-2n}{2} = \frac{n(n-2)}{2} $$. Now there are $$n$$ vertices, it would be nice if we could show each vertex has at least degree $$n-2$$, because then we can use the handshaking lemma and directly prove it.

As for the contradiction, if some vertex $$u$$ has at most degree of $$n-3$$, there are $$n$$ vertices, $$u$$ can link to a max of $$n-1$$ other vertices (we know $$u$$ can't link to itself), that means there are at least 2 vertices ($$v,w$$ arbitrary) to which $$u$$ is not linked to. Pick these 3 vertices: $$u,v,w$$, and you've got a triple that contradicts.

The second intuition is, $$\frac{n^2}{2} -n$$ looks very sus, so why not manipulate it a bit, and we get $$\frac{n^2}{2} -\frac{2n}{2} = \frac{n^2-2n}{2} = \frac{n(n-2)}{2} $$. Now there are $$n$$ vertices, it would be nice if we could show each vertex has at least degree $$n-2$$, because then we can you the handshaking lemma and directly prove it.

As for the contradiction, if some vertex $$u$$ has at most degree of $$n-3$$, there are $$n$$ vertices, $$u$$ can link to a max of $$n-1$$ other vertices (we know $$u$$ can't link to itself), that means there are at least 2 vertices ($$v,w$$ arbitrary) to which $$u$$ is not linked to. Pick these 3 vertices: $$u,v,w$$, and you've got a triple that contradicts.

history.subject: Module 12 self paced example
history.content: I am reading through the proof but I do not understand this part and the below lines - so by using contradiction G is divided into 3 or more CCs. What does it mean that "e appears in all three of these paths"?

We wanted to prove that removing a cut edge $$e$$ increases the number of CCs by 1. This means the CC that $$e$$ is in must be split into exactly 2 CCs. We assume for contradiction that the removal of $$e$$ increases the number of CCs by more than 1 (so the CC $$e$$ is in gets split into 3 or more CCs). We'll consider 3 of these CCs and all them $$D_1, D_2, D_3$$.

Let $$w_1 \in D_1, w_2 \in D_2, w_3 \in D_3$$ be vertices. Remember that before removing $$e$$, $$D_1, D_2, D_3$$ were all 1 CC, so all these vertices must be connected to each other. So we can say there exists paths $$w_1 - \cdots - w_2$$, $$w_2 - \cdots - w_3$$, and $$w_1 - \cdots - w_3$$. Note that these paths no longer exist after removing $$e$$ because we split this CC into at least 3 CCs. Hence, $$e$$ must be on all these paths (otherwise the paths would still be intact).

For any tree if we add one edge between any two existing vertices the resulting graph is not
bipartite.

- or is it just when this edge is added separately in different scenarios/

This claim is saying that if you start with a tree, no matter which edge you add to it (so long as it does not already exist), the resulting graph will be not bipartite.

history.subject: Additional final Practice #16
history.content:
In the proof on the solutions, it says:

\\

With this we can say that the graph must
have an even number of vertices because there are only odd degree vertices.
\\
What is the broader logic behind this?

$$\sum_{v \in V} \deg(v) = 2|E|$$. This tells us that the sum of the degrees of the vertices must be an even number. If there were an odd number of vertices, then $$\sum_{v \in V} \deg(v)$$ would be odd (the sum of and odd amount of odd numbers is odd), but that's a contradiction.

history.content:
For arbitrary n ≥ 2, give an example of a set X and a function g : X → [1..n] that is not

injective and moreover | Ran(g)| = n − 1.

The answer is

DefineX=[1..n]andforeach1 ≤ k ≤ n define

g(k) =

k if 1 ≤ k ≤ n − 1 n−1 if k=n.

--

Are we able to say that the range of the answer is n - 1 because the nth term is not getting mapped to. Does this mean that range is how many values in the codomain are getting mapped to? Not just how many values are in the codomain? Thanks!

history.subject: Range of codomain
history.content:
For arbitrary n ≥ 2, give an example of a set X and a function g : X → [1..n] that is not

injective and moreover | Ran(g)| = n − 1.

The answer is

DefineX=[1..n]andforeach1 ≤ k ≤ n define

g(k) =

k if 1 ≤ k ≤ n − 1 n−1 if k=n.

--

Are we able to say that the range of the answer is n - 1 because the nth term is not getting mapped to. Does this mean that range is how many values in the codomain are getting mapped to? Not just how many values are in the codomain? Thanks!

The range is the set of values in the codomain that are being mapped to. That is, for a function $$g: X \mapsto Y$$, we have $$y \in Ran(g)$$ if $$\exists x \in X$$ such that $$g(x) = y$$. And we see that $$Ran(g) \subseteq Y$$.

history.subject: dag acyclic Q20
history.content:
From final review answers Q20, direct quote:

"Assume, for the purpose of contradiction, that it is not a path. Then we must have some vertex v that appears more than once in P. Let P′ be the part of this walk that starts at v and then returns to v, and let v′ be the second-to-last vertex in P′. Since we have a walk from v to v′, we must also have a path from v to v′, so this path plus the edge v′ → v creates a directed cycle, contradicting the fact that slugs are acyclic."

On the exam, is it sufficient to infer "FSOC, P is not a path. Then we must have some vertex v that appears more than once in P" $$\Rightarrow$$ "there exists a cycle in P, DAG is acyclic, contradiction"?

children.subject: Why don't we need to prove for the cases where we delete an edge that is not connected to a leaf? Or not in the cycle?

You need to prove it for an arbitrary graph. We have two cases that this graph falls under. 

In the first case we are guaranteed there will be an edge connected to a leaf, so we choose to remove that edge.

In the second case we are guaranteed there will be an edge in the cycle, so we choose to remove that edge.

In induction, we can choose how we reduce the k+1 instance to the k instance as long as that reduction holds for any arbitrary k+1 instance.

history.subject: Final Review Q15
history.content: Would it be valid to insert a vertex between the start and end of a cycle with k vertices using the induction hypothesis?

I'm not sure what you're asking so correct me if I misunderstood your question. I interpreted your question as starting with a 2-regular graph with k nodes. Then apply IH. Then add a vertex somewhere in the middle of that cycle.

For generality, let us call the property in the problem as $$P$$. Note that in this case, the property is that the graph is $$2$$-regular.

This runs into the issue with going from $$k$$ to $$k+1$$ in induction step. The only problem with this is that this only works if for all $$k+1$$-vertex graph with property $$p$$, there exists a $$k$$-vertex graph with the properties in the IH. So you would have to prove this in order to go from $$k$$ to $$k+1$$. Why do we need this? Because if not all $$k+1$$-vertex graphs with property $$P$$ can be constructed in this manner, then you would end up only showing the claim is true for some specific $$k+1$$-vertex graphs with property $$P$$ rather than for all.

We bypass this issue by starting with an arbitrary $$k+1$$-vertex graph with property $$P$$, then do something to it in order to apply IH. Now this proves it is true for all $$k+1$$-vertex graphs with property $$P$$.

history.subject: Final Review Problems #6e
history.content: The solution for 6b says that because a non-cut edge implies a cycle, there must be 3 non-cut edges to create the cycle. But can't you create a cycle using cut edges?

A cut edge is an edge whose removal will result in strictly more connected components than originally. Consider a graph with a cycle in it. Consider the connected component that cycle is in. If you remove an edge on the cycle, the component will remain connected, thus not increasing the number of connected components. Hence, none of the edges in the cycle can be cut edges. (Note: this is not a formal proof, just a quick sketch)

children.subject: What about a directed graph with a single vertice v and edge (v, v)?

Cut edges are only defined on undirected graphs because connected components are only defined on undirected graphs. I do not believe we have defined an equivalent terminology for a directed edge whose removal increases the number of strongly connected components in a directed graph.

history.subject: Recitation 9, problem 3
history.content: why are we taking copies of K3 ?

The graph $$G$$ is constructed by two copies of $$K_3$$ connected by an edge in the middle. The question asks how many subgraphs of $$G$$ that contain all the vertices and are connected.

Any connected subgraph of $$G$$ must have the middle edge, so now we have to ask ourselves in how many ways can we keep/remove edges from the two copies of $$K_3$$ and still have a connected graph? As long as both are connected and we have the middle edge, the entire subgraph will be connected.

Hence, we consider just one of the copies of $$K_3$$. We find that there is 1 way to remove zero edges and 3 ways to remove one edge from a $$K_3$$ and keep it connected. Now we can apply the same concept to the other $$K_3$$. By MR, there are $$4 \cdot 4 = 16$$ ways to remove edges from both copies of $$K_3$$ to keep both of them connected.

history.subject: HW9 Q3 min degree is at most 2?
history.content: What does "minimum degree in the graph must be at most two" exactly mean? Does it mean that there exists a vertice in the graph with a degree that is less than or equal than 2?

The minimum degree $$\delta(G)$$ is the degree of the vertex with the fewest number of edges.  So having $$\delta(G) \le 2$$ means the vertex with the fewest number of edges will have degree less than or equal to 2. So yes, you will know there exists a vertex in the graph with degree less than or equal to 2.

Note that all degrees in the graph are going to be greater than or equal to the minimum degree. We can write this as $$\forall v, deg(v) \ge \delta(G)$$. We can't really combine this with $$\delta(G) \le 2$$ very nicely, so that is why we took the contrapositive of the statement, giving us the assumption that $$\delta(G) > 2$$. Now we can combine to get $$\forall v, deg(v) \ge \delta(G) > 2$$, so now we know every vertex has degree at least 3.

history.subject: Is an acyclic graph with only one connected component still a forest?
history.content: Or must a forest be a collection of disjoint trees, while simply a tree is a connected acyclic graph? Are all trees forests?

history.subject: Question on double induction
history.content: Hi, I was trying to work through this and I get to the point where for i, I can use induction to say k can reach i + 1 and j can reach j + 1. Do I need to also mention how these two claims together prove that i, j is reachable from k,l. I am struggling with that part a bit

The first induction should prove $$\forall x$$, $$(k, x)$$ can reach $$(i, x)$$ iff $$k \le i$$.

The second induction should prove $$\forall x$$. $$(x, \ell)$$ can reach $$(x, j)$$ iff $$\ell \le j$$.

Now let $$k, \ell, i, j$$ be arbitrary where $$k \le i$$ and $$\ell \le j$$. By our first induction, we can say $$(k, \ell)$$ can reach $$(i, \ell)$$. By our second induction, we can say $$(i, \ell)$$ can reach $$(i, j)$$.

history.subject: hw9 q6 clarifcation
history.content: Is the forward proof essentially saying that we distribute all of the vertices of A to one CC and all of the vertices in B to another CC

The contrapositive here wants to show that we can partition $$V$$ into two sets of vertices such that there are no edges between them. If there were only 2 connected components, then we would use those as our sets. However, there could be more than 2 connected components. So to handle all those cases we let one set be one component $$S$$, and the other set be all the other vertices $$V \setminus S$$ (which might span multiple connected components).

history.subject: graph induction cc
history.content:
Below is screenshot from the graph induction review section. How come reintroducing $$u$$ with $$\leq d$$ edges is sufficient for the induction step? Let us introduce a vertex with $$d \leq l < k+1$$ degrees, we end up with a graph with $$k+1$$ vertices and $$m-d+l$$ edges and this graph is not covered in our IS. How does the proof address this example? 

Or is it because after we reintroduce $$u$$, the graph has to again have exactly $$m$$ edges so $$u$$ can bring in at most $$d$$ edges? If so, why?

The IS covers all graphs because it says "let $$G$$ be a graph with $$m$$ edges on $$k+1$$ vertices." Note that $$m$$ is arbitrary, so this covers all possible graphs with $$k+1$$ edges.

In induction, you always start with some arbitrary $$k+1$$ graph, then remove something to apply your IH, then add what you removed back. Importantly, you need to add exactly what you removed back so that you end up with the same graph your IS started with.

children.subject: I see, so can we say that the graph with $$k+1$$ vertices is arbitrary but particular for the sake of the IS?
Sure

history.subject: HW11 Q5 - why is the base case 1?
history.content: I thought the base case has to be n=2 because the question states that between any 2 platforms a, b. Why does it suffice to show for n=1?

It states $$n \in \mathbb{Z^+}$$, so our base case must start at 1. The statement "between any two platforms ..." does not imply there must be 2 platforms.

To look at this another way, let's go back to sets. We say $$\emptyset \subseteq A$$, which means for all elements of $$\emptyset$$, the element is also in $$A$$. But there are no elements of the $$\emptyset$$, yet the claim is still true.

history.subject: Base cases for graphs
history.content: I am confused on what to have as our base case for induction on graphs. For certain problems with restrictions (for example we are dealing with cycles) then I assume we can start with n=3 but for questions without specifics on where n starts (sth like n >=4) then do we just start base case with 1 vertice? Or would you guys make it clear to state "use induction" on certain questions?

Similar to your previous question @1599. I would say your base case should always just follow from the bounds the problem provides. Oftentimes it will say there are $$n \in \mathbb{Z^+}$$ people or something, in which case your base case should be the smallest number in this set $$\mathbb{Z^+}$$.

Conditions that are "for all" will typically not imply a tighter bound (see @1599).

Conditions that are "there exists" may allow you to assume a tighter bound. For example, if it says there exists a cycle with ..., then you could assume a cycle exists and thus $$n \ge 3$$. Note that you don't have to always increase your bound, if you prove the claim is true for $$n \ge 1$$ then that also proves it is true for $$n \ge 3$$.

history.subject: Final Review Q11
history.content:
Can we use proof by contradiction with cases on the number of cycles in the graph to prove that G has exactly 1 cycle?

AFSOC: # of cycles in G \neq 1.

Case 1: # of cycles = 0

Then, G is a tree, and |E| = |V| - 1. Contradiction.

Case 2: # of cycles \geq 2

Case a: Cycles don't share edges. Then the graph is disconnected. Contradiction.

Case b: Cycles do share \geq 1 edges(s). Then |E| > |V|. Contradiction.

Hence, G has exactly 1 cycle.
Yeah this should be fine if you flesh out the explanations for case a and case b.

history.subject: Walks and paths
history.content:
It says that a walk is a non-empty sequence. Can a path be empty sequence? Because I think I saw problems where we state paths of length 0. But where there is a walk there is a path - doesn't this mean we need walks of length 0 too? Also, does this differ for directed graphs? 

Furthermore, it says u and v are connected if there exists some walk with endpoints u and v, but a graph is connected if there is a path between every pair of vertices. Does it not matter if it's a walk or path?

A walk is a non-empty sequence of vertices consecutively linked by edges. I think you're thinking it as a non-empty sequence of edges, which is different. Because it is defined on vertices, a single-vertex sequence is a valid walk as well as a valid path.

A directed walk is a non-empty sequence of vertices consecutively linked by directed edges.

If there exists a walk between $$u$$ and $$v$$, there exists a path between them as well.

A walk is a non-empty sequence of vertices consecutively linked by edges. I think you're thinking it as a non-empty sequence of edges, which is different. Because it is defined on vertices, a single-vertex sequence is a valid walk as well as a valid path.

A directed walk is a non-empty sequence of vertices consecutively linked by directed edges. If there exists a walk between $$u$$ and $$v$$, there exists a path between them as well.

history.content: For 4b, why is the answer not 6n(n-1) + 6n(n-1)(n-2)? Would the paths of length 3 be different if you started the path with a blue vertex instead of a red vertex, which is why you would also add 6n(n-1)(n-2) to account for paths starting with blue vertex?

history.subject: Final exam review Q4b
history.content: For 4b, why is the answer not 2 * 6n(n-1)? Would the paths of length 3 be different if you started the path with a blue vertex instead of a red vertex, which is why you would multiply by factor of 2?

If you try to count paths starting with blue, then you would have $$n \cdot 3 \cdot (n-1) \cdot 2 = 6n(n-1)$$ as well. However, you should only count either paths that start with red or paths that start with blue, because reversing the path results in the same path. For example, having R1-B1-R2-B2 is the same as B2-R2-B1-R1. If you count these separately, you would be double counting each path.

history.subject: Question from HW 11 regarding dags
history.content: I know that dags need to have at least once source and one sink. However, if i'm correct, DAG's do not have to be connected. Therefore, why for part 2b do we assume that for any arbitrary vertice there is a path from the source to that vertice and a path from that vertice to a sink. Moreover, if we had a graph of n vertices that do NOT share any edges in between them, would this still count as. DAG with a topological sort, etc.

We do not assume these. We prove that for every vertex $$v$$, there exists a source that has a direct path to $$v$$. We also prove that for every vertex $$v$$, there exists a direct path from $$v$$ to a sink. Note that these prove "there exists" a source/sink, not that all sources have a direct path to $$v$$ or $$v$$ has a direct path to all sinks.

A directed graph with no direct edges is still a direct acyclic graph and does have a topological sort.

children.subject: So you're basically showing an example but this is not true of all DAGS?
It is true for all DAGs. It is proving for all DAGs, for all vertices $$v$$, there exists a source that has a direct path to $$v$$. The proof does not give a specific example of a DAG.

If you are confused why this holds true for DAGs that are not "connected," consider the DAG with $$n$$ vertices and $$0$$ directed edges. Every vertex $$v$$ has a source (itself) that has a direct path to it. Also every vertex $$v$$ has a sink (itself) which $$v$$ has a direct path to.
Oh ok. So every vertex "v" in a DAG has a path from some source to v and from v to some sink?
Correct

history.subject: Explanation from Graph basics review session
history.content: Can anyone further explain this example, as I am not sure how this works since "v" does not have a degree of 2, since it is only connected to "y". I understand the concept but the way the proof was formed is tripping me up a bit, can any re-explanations of the proof be provided.

Since every vertex has a degree of at least two, we know this also holds true for the endpoints of the maximal path, $$u$$ and $$v$$. Since we know that $$u$$ is an endpoint on the maximal path, we know that one of its neighbors must also be on the path. But what about its other neighbor, (b/c it has degree at least 2) say $$z$$? We can split into cases:

Case 1: If $$z$$ is also on the path, then because $$u$$ is an endpoint, we can go from $$z$$ to $$u$$ following the path. But then we can also take the direct edge from $$u$$ to $$v$$, which creates a cycle.

Case 2: If $$z$$ is not on the path, then we can extend the path by going from $$v$$ to $$z$$ instead of $$v$$ to $$u$$. But by definition, maximal paths cannot be extended, so this is a contradiction.

Therefore, we must have a cycle.

history.subject: HW11Q5
history.content: I don't understand the logic with the contradiction statement, how do you get from (v_1, v) exists to (v_2, v) exists

We assume for contradiction that no such $$i$$ exists where we have edges $$(v_i, v)$$ and $$(v, v_{i+1})$$. Since we have $$(v_1,v)$$, there are 2 cases, either we have $$(v, v_2)$$ or we have $$(v_2, v)$$. If we have $$(v, v2)$$, then we have found an $$i$$ (namely $$i=1$$) such that we have $$(v_1, v)$$ and $$(v, v_2)$$. But this would reach a contradiction, so we proceed to the other case where we have $$(v_2, v)$$ instead.

You could think of it as at each step there are 2 cases, one of which will lead to a contradiction, and the other one continues the proof. We need to reach a contradiction on every case, so we continue with the one that doesn't lead to a contradiction. However, eventually that one will lead to a contradiction as well.

Then, we can choose TA 1 and TA 2 to be the ones that get 2 or more papers and still give TA 3 2 or more papers, and we can also choose TA 2 and TA 3 and repeat it but they seem like the same thing.

This doesn't overcount because the designation of being a Head TA is not the same as having at least 2 papers. There could be many TAs with at least 2 papers, all we know is that the Head TAs definitely get at least 2 papers.

If the question was 2 TAs get at least 2 papers and the rest gets at least 1 paper, then this would overcount, because we don't have anything to distinguish the TAs that were guaranteed at least 2 papers vs TAs that were only guaranteed at least 1 paper but end up getting at least 2.

children.subject: Thank you. Then, would the answer be just not multiplying nC2?

It's a bit more complicated than that. If you don't choose the 2 TAs that get at least 2 papers, then you don't know which TAs you're giving at least 2 papers to. Instead, you would probably want to do complementary counting. You first make sure everyone gets at least 1 paper. Then you complementarily count the ways you don't have at least 2 TAs getting at least 2 papers.
Thank you. Then in this case, would it be just subtracting the case where 1 TA gets all the remaining papers after 1 has been given to all?

history.subject: clique and chromatic number
history.content:
In homework10 we proved that the chromatic number $$\chi(G)$$ is greater or equal to the size of the largest clique in $$G$$, $$\kappa (G)$$. The example we used to disprove $$\chi(G) = \kappa(G)$$ for all $$G$$ was the case of any odd cycle in $$G$$.

Therefore, would any graph $$G$$ that doesn't contain any odd cycle necessarily have $$\chi(G) = \kappa(G)$$?

Or, in other words, would $$\chi(G) = \kappa(G)$$ hold for any $$\chi(G) \geq 3$$?

In homework10 we proved that the chromatic number $$\chi(G)$$ is greater or equal to the largest clique in $$G$$, $$\kappa (G)$$. The example we used to disprove $$\chi(G) = \kappa(G)$$ for all $$G$$ was the case of any odd cycle.

Therefore, would any graph $$G$$ that doesn't contain any odd cycle necessarily have $$\chi(G) = \kappa(G)$$?

Would any graph $$G$$ that doesn't contain any odd cycle necessarily have $$\chi(G) = \kappa(G)$$?

We have shown that a graph without an odd cycle is bipartite. So it would remain to show that a graph with no odd cycles would have max clique size of $$2$$. It's pretty easy to show why this is true via contradiction (suppose you had a clique of size 3 or larger...)

history.subject: How to solve stars and bars with different conditions
history.content: If we want to distribute n stars to r people but we want all of them to have at least 1 star and exactly 3 of them to have at least 2 stars, how do we solve the problem? Also, what would happen if it was at least 3 people instead of exactly 3?

If there are $$n$$ people, and exactly 3 of them must have at least 2 star and the remaining $$n-3$$ people must have at least one star, then it must be the case that the $$n-3$$ people all have exactly one star. So give those people all one star, then do stars & bars with the remaining stars amongst the 3 people left. 

For the second question, you could probably do some complementary counting PIE type stuff.

children.subject: Sorry I don't understand - I have r people. I want all of them to have at least 1 star so I distribute them by subtracting r from n. Then, I want exactly 3 people to have at least 2. Does it suffice to just subtract 3 more from n-r? And then we do stars and bars?

well, when you do this, the remaining people will have 1 star (that they received from the first step) + more that they get from the last step. This would mean that you would have more than 3 people with at least 2 stars (whereas you wanted exactly 3 people with at least 2 stars).

history.subject: sufficient vs necessary
history.content: Hi could you please help me understand the difference between sufficient and necessary in terms of logical notation and how it is related to if-then statements. I am still a bit confused about this.

Passing CIS 1600 is sufficient to earn a CU. Here, passing CIS 1600 implies you get a CU. However, there are ways to get CUs without taking CIS 1600, so getting a CU implies passing CIS 1600 is not true.

It is necessary to pass CIS 1600 to get a CIS degree at Penn. Here, getting a CIS degree at Penn implies you had passed CIS 1600. But passing CIS 1600 does not imply you got a CIS degree at Penn (for example if you haven't graduated yet).

Yes to the first question. If you have $$k$$ edges, then the number of spanning subgraphs would be $$2^k$$

history.subject: Does being minimally connected imply a graph is acyclic, and vice versa?

history.content:
$$G$$ is minimally connected $$\Rightarrow G$$ is a tree $$\Rightarrow G$$ is acyclic.

BUT acyclic does not necessarily mean connected. Take any edgeless graph.   However, it's true that $$G$$ is acyclic $$\Rightarrow G$$  is a forrest $$\Rightarrow $$ every connected component in $$G$$ is a tree

minimally connected $$\Rightarrow $$ tree $$\Rightarrow $$ acyclic.

BUT acyclic does not necessarily mean connected. Take any edgeless graph.   However, it's true that acyclic $$\Rightarrow $$ forrest $$\Rightarrow $$ every connected component is a tree

minimally connected $$\Rightarrow $$ tree $$\Rightarrow $$ acyclic.

BUT acyclic does not necessarily mean connected. Take any edgeless graph.   However, it's true that acyclic $$\Rightarrow $$ forrest $$\Rightarrow $$ any connected component is a tree
